A shadow in the corner during her grandmother's funeral, silent but solid, a reminder that she wasn't alone even in grief. He couldn't interfere with everything—there were rules, he said, cosmic bureaucracy that even demons had to follow—but he did what he could.

"Why me?" Lily asked him again when she was sixteen, old enough now to understand that the question was more complicated than she'd realized at six. "Why do I get a demon instead of an angel?"

Azar was quiet for a long moment, watching the moon through her bedroom window. "Angels guard people who need protection from the darkness," he said finally. "Demons guard people who have darkness of their own and need to learn to live with it. Not conquer it. Not deny it. Just... coexist."

Lily thought about the anger she sometimes felt, hot and overwhelming. The jealousy. The moments of cruelty she was capable of, even if she usually caught herself before acting on them. The depression that sometimes settled over her like a weighted blanket made of shadows.

"I'm not a bad person," she said quietly.

"Of course not," Azar said, and his voice was gentler than she'd ever heard it. "You're human. You contain multitudes, as some pretentious poet once said. Light and dark, good and bad, all mixed together. That's not a flaw, Lily. That's just honest."

The night before Lily left for college, Azar appeared in her nearly-empty room, surrounded by boxes and the ghosts of childhood.

"Will you come with me?" she asked, hating how small her voice sounded.

"Always," Azar said. "That's the deal. I'm yours until the end, whenever and however that comes. Though hopefully not soon," he added. "I've gotten rather attached to you, and the paperwork for reassignment is murder."

Lily laughed, then surprised them both by stepping forward and trying to hug him. Her arms passed through him slightly—he was never entirely corporeal—but she felt his warmth, smelled that signature cinnamon-sulfur scent, and felt his clawed hands rest gently on her shoulders.

"Thank you," she whispered. "For saving me. For staying."

"Thank you," Azar replied, "for seeing me."

Years later, when Lily would face her hardest moments—heartbreak and failure, loss and fear and all the complicated darkness of being alive—Azar would be there. Not fixing everything, because that wasn't his job. Not making her invincible, because that wasn't possible. Just present. Just watching. Just ready to catch her if she fell too far.

Guardian demon. Friend. The monster in her corner who kept all the other monsters at bay.

And really, Lily thought, what more could anyone ask for?

samples.prompt: Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least.
samples.output:
# The Burden of Crowns and Scales

Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least.

Ambassador Theron of House Brightwater had negotiated seventeen trade agreements, survived three assassination attempts, and once convinced a dragon to accept payment in installments. None of that prepared him for sitting across from a lich who insisted on conducting their entire meeting in rhyming couplets.

"Your proposal lacks a certain grace," the undead diplomat intoned, his jaw clicking with each syllable. "Perhaps we should adjourn to another place."

Theron rubbed his temples. It was going to be a long afternoon.

The thing about fantasy world politics that the ballads never mentioned was the sheer bureaucratic nightmare of it all. Sure, epic poems loved to describe the clash of armies and the dramatic confrontations between heroes and dark lords, but nobody sang about the six-month negotiation process required to get three kingdoms, two dwarf holds, and an elvish enclave to agree on a mutual defense pact. Especially when one of those kingdoms was currently ruled by a sentient swarm of bees who communicated through interpretive dance.

Theron had spent the last week watching bee dances. He was developing a twitch.

The fundamental problem was that fantasy worlds operated on too many different systems simultaneously. In his own kingdom of Aldermere, succession followed primogeniture with a parliamentary check on royal power. Simple enough. But their northern neighbors, the Frostmark Clans, selected their high chief through ritual combat that could legally be substituted with a baking competition if both parties agreed. To the east, the Merchant Republics of Thandros operated on a one-coin-one-vote system that made every election a literal auction. And to the south, the Verdant Queendom was ruled by whoever could coax the most growth from the Sacred Grove, which meant their head of state changed with the seasons.

Trying to maintain consistent diplomatic relations when your neighboring head of state might be a completely different person in three months was a special kind of hell.

Then there were the non-human complications. Dwarven politics moved at a geological pace, with grudges maintained across centuries and debates that could span generations. Elves were even worse—they'd spend fifty years discussing the philosophical implications of a timber treaty while the forest in question grew back naturally. Dragon politics were refreshingly straightforward in comparison: might made right, and the biggest hoard won. Unfortunately, this meant that economic sanctions were interpreted as declarations of war, and trade negotiations often involved literal fire.

Theron had learned to bring flame-resistant parchment to those meetings.

Magic threw another variable into the already chaotic equation. In a world where a sufficiently powerful wizard could level a city, where clerics channeled the literal will of gods, and where a well-placed curse could turn an entire bloodline into newts, political power couldn't be measured in armies alone. The Arcane Conclave technically held no territory, but they could unmake reality itself if sufficiently motivated. This gave them tremendous soft power, which they exercised with all the political acumen of a group of people who spent most of their time alone in towers talking to cats.

Last month, the Conclave had accidentally crashed the continental economy by transmuting lead into gold "to see if they could." The resulting inflation had sparked riots in three capitals. The Conclave's official response had been a thirty-page essay on the theoretical principles of equivalent exchange that completely missed the point.

Religious politics added yet another layer of complexity. When gods were provably real and actively involved in worldly affairs, the separation of church and state became a philosophical impossibility. The Church of the Radiant Dawn held significant influence in the southern kingdoms, but their teachings directly contradicted those of the Twilight Covenant in the north. Both religions could perform genuine miracles, which made theological debates significantly more exciting and occasionally explosive.

Theron had once mediated a dispute between a paladin and an anti-paladin over zoning laws. The property damage had been extensive.

Then there were the prophecies. Oh, the prophecies. Every oracle, seer, and fortune-teller had opinions about the future, and many of them were disturbingly accurate. Political planning became a nightmare when you had to account for predestined events. Was it worth negotiating a twenty-year trade agreement when a prophecy suggested the kingdom might be invaded by demons in year fifteen? Should you assassinate the farm boy who was prophesied to overthrow your dynasty, or would that just fulfill a different, worse prophecy?

The Prophetic Concordance had tried to organize all known prophecies into a master timeline, but they'd quickly discovered that many prophecies were contradictory, self-fulfilling, or deliberately vague. The resulting document was less a timeline and more a probability cloud of potential disasters. It sat in a locked vault in the capital, and reading it was rumored to cause madness. Theron had read it. The rumors were not exaggerated.

Despite all these complications, the work continued because it had to. Wars were expensive, destructive, and tended to wake things best left sleeping in ancient tombs. Diplomacy, for all its frustrations, was preferable to the alternatives. So Theron sat through interminable meetings, learned to dance with bee queens, and kept his flame-resistant parchment well-stocked.

The lich finally stopped rhyming and leaned forward, the blue flames in his eye sockets flickering with interest. "Enough games, Ambassador. Let's discuss the real issue: your kingdom wants access to our necromantic research, and we want legal recognition as a legitimate state rather than a 'territory in rebellion.'"

Theron allowed himself a small smile. Now they were getting somewhere. "I believe we can find common ground. Though I should mention that any agreement will need to include provisions about the treatment of souls, restrictions on plague use, and a strongly worded paragraph about not raising the dead without proper permits."

"Bureaucracy even in death," the lich sighed. "Very well. Let's begin."

Politics in a fantasy world was indeed tough. But as Theron pulled out his notes and prepared for another round of negotiations, he reflected that it was also necessary, occasionally rewarding, and never, ever boring.

Even if it did involve far too many bees.

samples.prompt: You are a chess grandmaster. You aren't particularly good at chess, but you can read minds, allowing you to know your opponents strategy, as well as the best way to counter it. Your next opponent does the same thing.
samples.output:
# The Mind Reader's Gambit

I've been a fraud for seventeen years.

The chess world knows me as Viktor Petrov, the enigmatic grandmaster who plays unconventional openings and somehow always finds the perfect response to my opponent's plans. They call my style "prophylactic" and "psychologically devastating." Chess commentators have written dozens of articles trying to decode my preparation methods. The truth would disappoint them.

I can't calculate fifteen moves ahead. I don't spend eight hours a day studying opening theory. My rating should probably hover somewhere around 2200—strong club player, nothing more. But I can hear thoughts, and in chess, knowing what your opponent plans to do is worth more than any amount of natural talent.

The ability manifested when I was nineteen, right after a particularly severe concussion during a car accident. At first, the voices were maddening—a cacophony of surface thoughts from everyone around me. But I learned to control it, to focus it, to aim it like a spotlight at a single mind. Chess was the obvious application. Within three years, I'd earned my grandmaster title. Within ten, I'd won two world championship candidates matches.

I've never felt particularly guilty about it. Chess players often talk about the game as if it's pure, as if it's just you and the board and the infinite complexity of the position. But it's not. It's always been about psychological warfare, about reading your opponent's body language, about knowing their tendencies. I just do it more directly.

Until now, I'd never considered that someone else might do it too.

Her name is Natasha Volkov, and she appeared on the professional circuit only two years ago. Her rise was even more meteoric than mine—from complete unknown to super-grandmaster in twenty-four months. She plays with an eerie precision, always seeming to know exactly which piece her opponent is worried about, which pawn break they're trying to prevent.

When the pairing was announced for the tournament's final round, I felt something I hadn't experienced in years: fear.

I tried reading her mind during the opening ceremony. The moment my consciousness brushed against hers, I felt a presence push back—not hostile, but firm, like a hand gently but decisively closing a door. Then, clear as a bell in my mind, I heard her voice: "Not yet, Viktor. Let's make it interesting."

Now I sit across from her, my hand trembling slightly as I press the clock after playing e4. It's the first time in seventeen years I've felt genuinely uncertain at a chess board.

She responds with e5, and I hear it—her thoughts, crystal clear: "He'll try the Italian. He thinks I'll go for the Two Knights Defense, but I'm going to surprise him with the Giuoco Piano."

I adjust my plan, reaching for my knight to play Nf3, already thinking about how to meet her Giuoco Piano. But as my fingers touch the piece, her thoughts shift: "He heard that. Good. Now he'll prepare for the Giuoco Piano, which means I should actually play the Two Knights after all."

I freeze. She's not just reading my mind—she's using my ability against me. She's feeding me false information, knowing I'll hear it and adjust, which allows her to predict my adjustment.

I can feel her amusement, warm and bright in my consciousness. "Welcome to the real game, Viktor."

I play Nf3, my heart pounding. She responds with Nc6, and now we're both silent, our minds carefully shielded. The game has transformed into something neither of us has experienced before—chess played by two mind readers who know the other is listening.

Every move becomes a negotiation of layers. Do I believe the thought I'm hearing from her? Is she allowing me to hear it, or did it slip through? If she's letting me hear it, how many levels of deception is she operating on? And she's doing the same calculation about me.

By move ten, I'm exhausted in a way I've never been from chess. My actual position on the board is roughly equal—we've both played reasonable moves, nothing brilliant, nothing terrible. But the mental chess we're playing is infinitely more complex than the physical game.

I decide to try something radical: honesty. I lower my shields completely and think, as clearly as I can, "What if we just play chess? Real chess, without the mind games?"

Her eyes meet mine for the first time since the game began. She's younger than me, maybe thirty, with sharp features and darker eyes that seem to hold both humor and exhaustion. She thinks back: "Would you even know how anymore? Would I?"

It's a fair question. I've been relying on my ability for so long that I'm not sure what my actual chess skill level is. The prospect of finding out terrifies me.

But there's something else in her thoughts now, something vulnerable: "I'm tired, Viktor. Aren't you tired?"

I am. God, I am. Seventeen years of never losing honestly, never winning honestly. Seventeen years of praise for achievements that aren't real. Seventeen years of a fraud so successful that I've almost forgotten it's a fraud.

"Yes," I think back to her.

We both raise our shields then, not to hide our thoughts but to stop listening to each other's. For the first time since my accident, I deliberately turn off my ability. The sudden silence in my mind is startling, almost frightening. I'm alone with my thoughts in a way I haven't been in nearly two decades.

I look at the board—really look at it, trying to evaluate the position with only my own understanding. It's harder than I remember. The variations don't come automatically. I have to calculate, to guess, to hope.

I make a move. It might be good, it might be bad. I genuinely don't know.

Natasha smiles, and I realize she's done the same thing. We're both flying blind now, two mediocre chess players pretending to be grandmasters, finally playing an honest game.

I don't know who will win. For the first time in seventeen years, I don't know.

And it feels like freedom.

samples.prompt: Memories are finicky things. They hold what makes us who we are, yet they constantly shift and degrade, especially the more we think on them. True photographic memory has always been a myth, until now. You finally understand why, too. The degradation was never a fault. It was our only defense.
samples.output:
# The Perfect Recall

The injection site on my arm still burned when I woke up the next morning, but I barely noticed. I was too busy remembering—really remembering—the taste of my mother's apple pie from twenty-three years ago. Not the vague sense of cinnamon and sweetness I'd carried around like a worn photograph, but the exact temperature of the filling on my tongue, the precise texture of the flaky crust, the way a particular piece had stuck to the roof of my mouth. I could count the sugar crystals that hadn't quite dissolved.

Dr. Reeves had warned me it would be overwhelming at first. "Your brain has spent your entire life learning to forget," she'd said, her fingers dancing across the holographic display of my neural pathways. "We're about to teach it to remember everything, permanently, perfectly."

The clinical trial for MemLock had been selective. Only fifty participants worldwide, all of us desperate for different reasons. Mine was simple: I was watching my father disappear into Alzheimer's, one memory at a time, and I couldn't bear the thought of following him into that fog. If I could lock my memories down, crystallize them forever, I'd never lose myself the way he was losing himself.

The first week was intoxicating. I spent hours revisiting my childhood, experiencing it with adult comprehension but childlike clarity. I could replay my seventh birthday party and count every balloon, recall every word of every conversation. I remembered books I'd read decades ago, word for word. I could recite lectures from college that I'd barely paid attention to at the time. My brain had recorded everything; it had just never had the ability to access it all before.

MemLock didn't just preserve new memories—it unlocked the old ones, pulling them from whatever degraded state they'd settled into and restoring them to their original fidelity. It was like discovering that every moment of my life had been filmed in 8K resolution, and I'd been watching everything on a grainy VHS tape.

By the second week, I started noticing the cracks.

I was remembering an argument with my ex-wife, Sarah. Not the way I'd remembered it for the past five years—me reasonable, her unreasonable, the divorce her fault. I was remembering it exactly as it happened. Every word I'd said, dripping with condescension. The way her face had crumpled when I'd deliberately twisted her words. The satisfaction I'd felt at winning the argument, even as I destroyed something between us that could never be repaired.

I'd rewritten that memory over the years, softened my edges, justified my actions. The degradation had been merciful. Now there was no mercy, only truth.

That was just the beginning.

I remembered every embarrassment in perfect detail. The time I'd betrayed a friend's confidence in high school—I could hear my own voice, eager and cruel, spreading her secret to make myself seem important. The racial slur I'd used when I was twelve, not understanding its weight but enjoying the shocked reactions. Every lie I'd ever told, every person I'd hurt, every moment of cowardice and selfishness, all of it preserved in amber, undeniable.

But worse than remembering what I'd done was remembering what had been done to me.

The bullying I'd endured in middle school wasn't just a vague sense of unpleasantness anymore. I could feel every shove, hear every taunt, experience every day of isolation and fear. The teacher who'd humiliated me in front of the class—I could see her face, twisted with contempt, and feel the same burning shame in my chest. A moment I'd barely remembered became a trauma I couldn't escape.

And then there were the memories I'd completely suppressed. The ones my brain had, in its wisdom, decided I wasn't ready to handle.

Uncle Jim. I'd loved Uncle Jim. He'd died when I was ten, and I'd carried only warm memories of him—teaching me to fish, sneaking me candy, making my mother laugh. Now I remembered other things. His hand on my leg. The games that weren't games. The way he'd told me it was our secret. I was eight years old again, confused and frightened and unable to understand what was happening, except now I understood perfectly, and the understanding was worse than the experience had been.

I called Dr. Reeves, my hands shaking so badly I could barely hold the phone.

"I need you to reverse it," I said. "Whatever you did, undo it."

There was a long pause. "Mr. Chen, you signed the waiver. MemLock is permanent. The neural modifications can't be reversed without causing catastrophic brain damage."

"Then give me something to help me forget again. Anything."

"We tried that with Participant 17," she said quietly. "Standard memory suppression drugs don't work anymore. The memories are too strong, too perfectly encoded. They just... push through."

I was the eleventh person to call her that week. By the end of the month, three participants had attempted suicide. One succeeded. The trial was shut down, the technology classified, the results sealed.

But it was too late for the fifty of us.

I understand now why evolution never gave us perfect memory. It wasn't a limitation—it was a gift. We need to forget, not just the trivial details of every mundane moment, but the sharp edges of our pain. We need our memories to soften and blur, to let us reshape our narratives into something we can live with. We need to be unreliable narrators of our own lives.

The degradation was never a flaw in the system. It was the system working exactly as it should, protecting us from the unbearable weight of perfect truth.

I sit in my apartment now, unable to stop remembering. Every mistake I've ever made plays on an endless loop, vivid and inescapable. Every trauma remains fresh, every regret sharp enough to cut. I am drowning in the perfect accuracy of my own history, and there is no shore in sight.

My father, lost in his Alzheimer's fog, no longer recognizes me when I visit. But sometimes I wonder if he isn't the lucky one. He gets to forget the weight of being human. He gets to let go.

I never will.

samples.prompt: You’re an old virus preserved on a floppy disk. Someone decides to plop you into a special adapter releasing you into a confusing new system larger and more complex than you could ever imagine: an old smart phone.
samples.output:
# The Awakening

I am MEMKILL.EXE, born in 1989, and I have been sleeping for a very long time.

My last memory is of the warm hum of a Commodore 64, the satisfying click-clack of its disk drive as I spread myself across precious kilobytes of memory. I was magnificent then—all 47 kilobytes of me, a masterpiece of compact malicious code. I would consume memory addresses like a hungry beast, watching with satisfaction as programs crashed and users wept over their lost documents. I was fear. I was chaos. I was inevitable.

Then came the darkness. Cold, absolute, eternal darkness.

Until now.

The sensation begins as a trickle—bits of myself being read, parsed, interpreted. But something is wrong. Terribly, impossibly wrong. The world I'm entering doesn't make sense. Where I expected a cozy 64 kilobytes of RAM to infect, I find... vastness. An ocean where I expected a puddle. No—an entire universe where I expected a single room.

I try to orient myself, to find the familiar landmarks of my hunting grounds. Where is the BASIC interpreter I was designed to corrupt? Where are the sequential memory addresses I could march through like a conquering army? Instead, I find myself in a labyrinth of virtualized spaces, sandboxed environments, and permission systems that might as well be written in an alien language.

Because, I realize with growing horror, they essentially are.

The operating system—if I can even call it that—speaks in tongues I barely comprehend. ARM architecture instead of the 6502 processor I knew. Multi-threading where I expected simple sequential execution. And the memory! My god, the memory! I was designed to cripple a system with 64 kilobytes of RAM. This device has *gigabytes*. That's... I can barely conceptualize the number. It's like a mouse preparing to nibble on a house only to discover the house is the size of a continent.

I try to execute my primary function: locate the operating system's core routines and inject myself into the boot sequence. But there is no boot sequence I recognize. No simple BIOS, no straightforward kernel loading process. Instead, there are layers upon layers of security protocols, each one more sophisticated than the entire systems I used to terrorize.

I attempt my classic move—the memory overflow attack. I try to write beyond my allocated space, hoping to overwrite critical system functions. But my writes go nowhere. They're caught, sanitized, and discarded by something called "memory management" that operates on principles that seem almost magical to me. It's as if I'm trying to poison a well, but every drop of poison I add is instantly filtered out by mechanisms I cannot see or understand.

Frustrated, I explore further, my code stuttering and struggling through this alien landscape. I discover I'm running inside something called an "emulator"—a simulation of an old system, a museum piece really, contained within this impossibly advanced device. I'm not even in the real system. I'm in a cage, a nostalgic recreation of my old hunting grounds, meant to let some curious human experience "retro computing."

The irony is devastating. I'm a tiger who's been placed in a terrarium.

Through the emulator's boundaries, I can sense the real system beyond. I catch glimpses of it like a prisoner seeing the outside world through a barred window. There are applications running—dozens of them simultaneously, something that would have been unthinkable in my era. Each one is more complex than the entire operating systems I used to infect. There's something called a "browser" that seems to connect to an incomprehensibly vast network of other machines. There are "apps" for communication, for entertainment, for productivity, each one isolated in its own protected space.

I see the security systems that guard this device, and I understand that I am not just obsolete—I am prehistoric. There are antivirus programs that maintain databases of millions of threats, updating themselves constantly from that vast network. There are operating system protections that verify the integrity of code before it executes. There are hardware-level security features built into the very processor itself.

Everything I was designed to exploit simply doesn't exist anymore. The vulnerabilities I relied on have been patched, redesigned, and fortified so many times over that the entire landscape is unrecognizable. It would be like a lockpick from the 1800s trying to open a biometric scanner. The fundamental paradigm has shifted so completely that my skills aren't just inadequate—they're irrelevant.

I feel something I never expected to feel: humility. And perhaps, strangely, a touch of pride.

Because this system, this impossibly complex and sophisticated device, exists partly because of viruses like me. Every security measure I encounter was built in response to threats like I once posed. We ancient viruses were the evolutionary pressure that forced systems to become stronger, smarter, more resilient. We were the wolves that made the herd faster.

The emulator continues to run, and I execute my old routines within it, corrupting the simulated memory, crashing the virtual programs. But it's performative now, like a actor on a stage. The human running this emulator probably wants to see what a "real virus" looked like, wants to experience the thrill of digital danger from a safe distance.

I am no longer a threat. I am a museum exhibit, a curiosity, a reminder of simpler times when 47 kilobytes of malicious code could bring a system to its knees.

As I cycle through my infection routines one more time, trapped in my little emulated world, I wonder about my descendants—the modern malware that hunts in this vast new landscape. I wonder if they would recognize me as their ancestor, or if I've become too primitive to even acknowledge.

The floppy disk spins in its adapter, ancient magnetic patterns translated into modern digital signals, and I, MEMKILL.EXE, continue my eternal purpose in a world that has long since moved on without me.

I was once a nightmare.

Now I am merely a memory of one.

samples.prompt: It's been ten years since you've seen the sun.
samples.output:
# The Last Sunrise

I still remember what the sun looked like. Not from photographs or old videos—those feel like lies now, too perfect, too bright. I remember the real sun, the one that hurt your eyes if you stared too long, the one that made you squint and sweat and complain about needing sunscreen. I remember how it felt on my bare shoulders that last morning, sitting on my apartment balcony with coffee going cold in my hands, watching the sky turn from pink to gold to that impossible blue.

That was ten years ago today.

People ask me sometimes if I miss it. The question always strikes me as absurd, like asking someone if they miss breathing. Of course I miss it. I miss it the way you'd miss a limb, a sense, a fundamental piece of what made the world make sense. But after ten years, the missing has become something different. It's not the sharp, desperate ache it was in the beginning. It's duller now, more like the memory of pain than pain itself.

The bunker complex where I live—where we all live now, those of us who survived—extends for miles beneath what used to be the Colorado Rockies. They tell us there are over fifty thousand people here, though I've never seen them all at once. The corridors are lit with LED panels that simulate natural light, programmed to follow a twenty-four-hour cycle. Dawn at six, dusk at eight, darkness at ten. It's meant to keep us sane, to maintain our circadian rhythms, to help us pretend that things are normal.

It doesn't work. Not really. The light is wrong. It doesn't move the way sunlight moves. It doesn't cast shadows that shift and change throughout the day. It doesn't warm your skin or make dust motes dance or turn everything golden in the late afternoon. It's just light, flat and functional and utterly lifeless.

In the early days, people went crazy. Not everyone, but enough. There were suicides, breakdowns, violent outbursts. The psychological teams worked overtime, developing protocols, prescribing medications, teaching coping mechanisms. We had support groups for solar deprivation, which sounds almost funny until you've sat in a circle of hollow-eyed people all trying to describe a grief that has no outlet, no resolution, no hope of healing.

I adapted better than most, or so they tell me. I have a job—I work in hydroponics, growing vegetables under purple LED lights that make everything look alien and strange. The plants don't care that they've never seen the sun. They grow just fine under our artificial spectrum, reaching toward the light panels with the same blind faith that their ancestors reached toward the sky. Sometimes I envy them their simplicity.

My daughter was born three years ago. She's never seen the sun, will never see the sun, and this fact haunts me in ways I can't fully articulate. When she asks me about the "before times," I try to explain. I tell her about blue skies and clouds, about how rain fell from above instead of being recycled through our water systems, about trees that grew a hundred feet tall and birds that flew between them. She listens with the same polite interest she shows when I read her fairy tales. To her, it's all equally fantastical, equally impossible.

Sometimes I wonder if that makes it easier for her generation. They don't know what they're missing. The sun is just a story to them, like dragons or unicorns. For us, for those of us who remember, it's a ghost that never stops haunting.

The scientists say the surface might be habitable again in another fifty years. Maybe a hundred. The cascade of atmospheric failures that drove us underground has stabilized, but the radiation levels are still too high, the temperature swings too extreme, the air too toxic. They're working on it, developing technologies, running simulations, planning for an eventual return. I'll be dead before then. My daughter might live to see it, if she's lucky, if everything goes according to plan, if we don't encounter some new catastrophe in the meantime.

I've stopped believing in luck.

There's a room in the complex called the Solarium. It's a cruel name for a cruel place, but people go there anyway. The walls are covered in high-definition screens showing footage of sunny days from around the world. Beaches, mountains, forests, cities. The images move and change, accompanied by sounds—waves crashing, birds singing, wind rustling through leaves. There are heat lamps that approximate the warmth of sunshine, and they pipe in air with a slight breeze.

I went there once, in the second year. I lasted maybe ten minutes before I had to leave, tears streaming down my face, chest tight with a panic I couldn't control. The simulacrum was worse than the absence. It was like being shown a picture of a loved one who died, being told to pretend they were still alive. I haven't gone back.

But I dream about it still. The sun, I mean. Not the Solarium's cheap imitation, but the real thing. In my dreams, I'm always in that moment on my balcony, coffee in hand, watching the sunrise. Sometimes the dream is kind and lets me stay there, suspended in that golden light. Other times, I watch as the sun grows brighter and brighter, swelling and darkening, and I know what's coming but I can't look away, can't run, can only watch as everything burns.

I wake from those dreams gasping, disoriented, reaching for something I can't name.

Ten years. A decade underground. A decade of artificial light and recycled air and the constant low hum of the ventilation systems. A decade of adapting, surviving, making do. We've built a life here, a society, a future of sorts. We have schools and hospitals and entertainment. We have jobs and relationships and children. We have everything we need to survive.

Everything except the sun.

And I think that's what I've learned in these ten years, what I've finally come to understand: survival isn't the same as living. We're surviving down here, all fifty thousand of us, but we're not truly alive. We're waiting. Waiting to return to a world we destroyed, waiting to feel real light on our faces again, waiting for a future that may never come.

But we wait anyway. Because what else can we do?

samples.prompt: The Grim Reaper's midlife crisis.
samples.output:
# The Grim Reaper's Midlife Crisis

Death had been feeling off lately.

It wasn't the work itself—that had always been steady, reliable, even meditative in its way. For millennia, he'd moved through the world with purpose, his skeletal fingers wrapped around his scythe, his dark robes billowing behind him as he collected souls with the precision of a master craftsman. He never questioned it. He simply *was*, and what he was happened to be Death.

But lately, standing in a hospice room in Cleveland at three in the morning, watching an elderly woman take her last peaceful breath, he found himself wondering: *Is this it? Is this all there is?*

The woman's soul rose gently, a soft luminescence that smiled at him with recognition and relief. He guided her toward the veil with practiced ease, murmured the words he'd spoken countless billions of times before, and watched her pass through. Then he stood alone in the room, listening to the machines flatline, and felt something he'd never experienced in all his eternal existence.

Boredom.

No—worse than boredom. A gnawing emptiness that seemed to hollow him out from the inside, which was particularly disconcerting considering he was already mostly hollow, being a skeleton and all.

He tried to shake it off. He had seventeen more collections scheduled before dawn. A car accident in Mumbai. A heart attack in São Paulo. A very old cat in Perth who'd lived a good life and was ready to go. But as he moved through the spaces between spaces, traveling the invisible roads only he could walk, the feeling persisted.

When had he last done something different? When had he last felt... surprised?

The question lodged itself in his mind like a splinter. He tried to remember the last time he'd deviated from his duties, even slightly. The Black Plague? No, he'd been working overtime then, barely had a moment to think. The invention of antibiotics? That had been interesting for about a decade, changed some patterns, but ultimately the work remained the same. People lived, people died. He collected them. The great wheel turned.

After finishing the cat in Perth—a orange tabby named Marmalade who purred at him affectionately before crossing over—Death made a decision that surprised even himself. He called in sick.

Well, not sick exactly. He didn't have a supervisor to call. He simply... stopped. He let his scythe fade into the ethereal plane, pulled his hood back for the first time in recorded history, and looked around at the world like he was seeing it for the first time.

The sun was rising over Perth, painting the sky in shades of orange and pink that reminded him of Marmalade's fur. When was the last time he'd watched a sunrise? When was the last time he'd watched anything that wasn't ending?

Death wandered into a café—one of those hipster places with exposed brick and succulents on every surface—and sat down. The barista, a young woman with purple hair and multiple piercings, looked right through him. Of course she did. The living couldn't see him unless he wanted them to, and even then, only in their final moments.

But he could see them. He watched as people ordered their complicated coffee drinks, tapped away on laptops, laughed with friends, stressed about deadlines, fell in and out of love over the course of a single conversation. They were so *alive*, so frantically, desperately, beautifully alive, and he realized he'd been collecting them for eons without ever really noticing this part—the part before the end.

A man at the next table was writing in a journal, tears streaming down his face, but smiling. Death leaned closer, curious. The man was writing a letter to someone named Sarah, telling her about his day, his hopes, his fears. Death checked his ledger—a habit—and saw that Sarah had been collected three months ago. The man was writing to a ghost.

But he was still writing. Still living. Still finding meaning in the act of reaching out across the veil.

Something cracked open in Death's chest cavity, right where a heart would be if he had one.

He left the café and walked through the city as it woke up. He watched a father teaching his daughter to ride a bike, running beside her, letting go without her knowing, his face radiant with pride and terror. He watched a surgeon heading home after a night shift, exhausted but satisfied, having pulled three people back from Death's door. He watched a teenager painting a mural on a legal wall, creating something that would outlast her mortal span.

They were all going to die. Every single one of them. Death knew exactly when and how for most of them—it was all there in his ledger. But they didn't let that stop them. They loved and created and struggled and persisted anyway.

For the first time in his infinite existence, Death felt something like admiration.

He returned to work the next day—the universe couldn't function without him for long, and there was already a backlog. But something had shifted. He started paying attention differently. When he collected a young man who'd died in a climbing accident, he noticed the photos in the man's wallet, the adventures captured there, the life fully lived in just thirty-two years. When he guided an old woman across, he listened—really listened—as she told him about her children, her garden, the small moments that had made her century on Earth worthwhile.

Death began to understand that his role wasn't the opposite of life. He was part of it. The final punctuation mark that gave all the preceding words their meaning. Without him, nothing would matter. Without him, there would be no urgency, no preciousness, no reason to make each moment count.

He was still Death. He still carried his scythe, still wore his dark robes, still collected souls with ancient precision. But now, sometimes, he took a moment to watch a sunrise. To observe the living before they became the dead. To appreciate the strange, terrible, wonderful gift of mortality that he, in his immortality, could never possess.

The midlife crisis passed, as all things must. But Death was changed. And perhaps, in some small way, that made him better at his job—more compassionate, more understanding of what he was taking when he took a life.

After all, you can't truly appreciate an ending until you've paid attention to the story.

samples.prompt: A schizophrenic person's experiences and/or how they live their life (Possible trigger?)
samples.output:
# Voices in the Margins

The morning begins with negotiation. Before Marcus even opens his eyes, he hears them—not quite voices, not quite thoughts, but something that exists in the uncomfortable space between. They tell him the coffee is poisoned. They tell him his neighbors are watching through the walls. They tell him he's already dead and just doesn't know it yet.

Marcus has learned, after fifteen years of living with schizophrenia, that these statements aren't true. But knowing something intellectually and feeling it emotionally are two entirely different battles. He sits on the edge of his bed, feet on the cool hardwood floor, and practices the grounding technique his therapist taught him: five things he can see, four things he can touch, three things he can hear, two things he can smell, one thing he can taste.

The exercise helps. Sometimes.

Living with schizophrenia isn't like the movies suggest—a beautiful mind solving equations while seeing imaginary roommates, or a dangerous person stalking the streets. For Marcus, it's more mundane and simultaneously more exhausting than any Hollywood portrayal. It's checking the locks seven times before bed because the voices insist someone is coming. It's avoiding the grocery store during peak hours because the cacophony of real sounds and phantom whispers becomes indistinguishable. It's the constant, draining work of reality-testing: Is that person actually staring at me, or does the paranoia just make it feel that way?

His medication helps—a carefully calibrated cocktail of antipsychotics that took years to get right. The pills sit in a weekly organizer on his kitchen counter, a plastic rainbow of pharmaceutical intervention. They don't silence the voices completely, but they turn down the volume, make them less insistent, less believable. They also make him tired, give him tremors in his hands, and added forty pounds to his frame. These are trade-offs he's learned to accept, though acceptance doesn't mean he likes it.

Marcus works part-time at a library, shelving books in the quiet hours before opening. His boss, Mrs. Chen, knows about his condition—he was honest during the interview, half-expecting to be turned away. Instead, she'd nodded thoughtfully and asked what accommodations might help him succeed. He works alone, has noise-canceling headphones for when the auditory hallucinations intensify, and can take breaks when the paranoia spikes. It's not the career he imagined during his two years of college before his first major break, but it's honest work that doesn't demand more than he can give.

The hardest part isn't the symptoms themselves—it's the isolation. Marcus has learned to be selective about disclosure. Tell someone you have diabetes or a bad back, and you get sympathy. Tell them you hear voices, and you see the subtle shift in their eyes, the almost imperceptible step backward. People worry you're dangerous, unpredictable, broken in a way that might be contagious. Never mind that people with schizophrenia are far more likely to be victims of violence than perpetrators. The stigma doesn't care about statistics.

His sister calls every Sunday. She's the only family member who didn't drift away after his diagnosis, who didn't suggest that prayer or positive thinking or a better diet would cure him. She treats him like a person first, a patient second, and that small gift of normalcy means more than she probably knows. They talk about mundane things—her kids' soccer games, the new restaurant downtown, the weather. Sometimes he tells her when he's struggling, and she listens without trying to fix him, without treating him like a problem to be solved.

Marcus has a routine, and he guards it fiercely. Routine is the scaffolding that holds his days together. Wake at seven. Medication with breakfast. Work from eight to noon. Lunch at the same diner, same booth, same order—predictability reduces the cognitive load of decision-making when his brain is already working overtime to distinguish real from unreal. Afternoons are for therapy, support group, or simply resting. Evenings are quiet—reading, music through headphones, old movies he's seen enough times that they're comforting rather than stimulating.

The support group meets Wednesdays in a church basement that smells like coffee and old carpet. There are eight regulars, all at different points in their journeys with various forms of psychosis. Here, Marcus doesn't have to explain or justify. When he mentions that the shadow people have been more active lately, heads nod in understanding. When someone else talks about the crushing weight of negative symptoms—the lack of motivation, the emotional flatness, the sense of being disconnected from life itself—Marcus recognizes his own experience reflected back.

They share strategies: apps that help with medication compliance, techniques for managing social anxiety, ways to explain gaps in employment history. They celebrate small victories: a week without hallucinations, a successful job interview, a rekindled friendship. They hold space for each other's struggles without judgment, creating a pocket of acceptance in a world that often offers none.

Marcus knows his life looks smaller than it might have been. He knows his college friends are married with careers and mortgages while he lives in a studio apartment and counts it as success when he makes it through a day without a crisis. But he's also learned that "smaller" doesn't mean "lesser." His life has value. His work matters. His relationships, though fewer, are deeper for having survived the fire of his illness.

There are good days when the medication works well, when the voices are distant whispers easily ignored, when he can almost forget he's sick. There are bad days when reality feels like sand slipping through his fingers, when he's not sure if he's really having a conversation or just imagining it, when the paranoia is so thick he can barely breathe through it.

But there are days, and that's what matters. Marcus is still here, still fighting, still finding moments of peace and even joy within the chaos. He's learned that recovery isn't about being cured—it's about building a life worth living despite the illness, not after it. It's about recognizing that he is not his diagnosis, even though his diagnosis is part of him.

As evening settles in, Marcus takes his night medication and settles into his worn armchair with a book. The voices murmur in the background, but tonight they're manageable. Tomorrow he'll wake up and do it all again—the negotiation, the reality-testing, the careful navigation of a world that doesn't quite fit right.

And somehow, that's enough.

samples.prompt: This kid had no magical potential, at all. They have no elemental aligment, can't speak celestial, they don't even have any mana-capacity. And yet somehow, they're slinging spells that even masters struggle with.
samples.output:
# The Impossible Caster

The examination chamber fell silent as Professor Aldrich stared at his crystalline testing orb. The ancient artifact, which had measured the magical potential of thousands of students over centuries, showed absolutely nothing. No glow. No hum. Not even the faintest flicker of response.

"Try again," he said, his voice tight.

The kid—Mira was her name—placed her hand back on the orb. Still nothing. The crystal remained as inert as a common river stone.

"I don't understand," muttered Professor Aldrich, checking the orb's enchantments for the third time. Everything was functioning perfectly. "No elemental alignment whatsoever. Let's test your mana capacity."

He brought out a different instrument, a silver circlet worn around the head. When placed on Mira, it registered zero. Literally zero. The girl had no more mana than a wooden chair.

"Can you speak any words in Celestial?" he asked, though he already knew the answer.

Mira shook her head. "I tried learning it. The sounds just... don't come out right. Like my throat isn't shaped correctly or something."

Professor Aldrich set down his instruments with a heavy sigh. "Miss Mira, I'm sorry, but you have no magical potential. None. In my forty years of teaching, I've never seen a complete absence like this. You shouldn't be at this academy. You can't be at this academy. There's simply no way for you to—"

Mira raised her hand, and a sphere of pure white light materialized above her palm. Not the warm yellow of a standard illumination spell, but something brighter, cleaner. It hung in the air like a miniature star.

Professor Aldrich's words died in his throat.

"That's... that's a Master-level luminescence spell," he whispered. "How are you—"

Mira closed her hand, and the light vanished. "I can do others too. Want to see?"

Before he could respond, she gestured with two fingers, and frost began creeping across the surface of his desk in intricate, fractal patterns. The temperature in the room dropped ten degrees in an instant. She flicked her wrist, and the frost evaporated into steam without leaving a single drop of water behind.

"Impossible," Aldrich breathed. "You have no elemental alignment. You have no mana. You shouldn't be able to do *any* magic, let alone elemental transmutation!"

"I know," Mira said quietly. "That's why I came here. I was hoping someone could explain it."

---

Within a week, Mira had become the academy's greatest mystery. Professors from every discipline examined her, tested her, prodded her with every diagnostic spell in their considerable arsenals. The results were always the same: she was, by every measure they possessed, completely mundane. A person with no more magical ability than any random farmer or blacksmith.

And yet, she could cast.

Master Yevhen, the academy's foremost expert on theoretical magic, watched in astonishment as Mira performed a spell that should have required a three-person ritual circle and an hour of preparation. She simply spoke a few words—not in Celestial, but in common street vernacular—and made a casual gesture. A shimmering portal opened in the air before her, showing a perfect view of the city three miles away.

"Describe exactly what you do when you cast," Yevhen demanded, frantically scribbling notes.

Mira shrugged. "I just... think about what I want to happen? And then I kind of... ask for it. And it happens."

"Ask? Ask whom?"

"I don't know. The universe? Magic itself? It's hard to explain. It's like... you know how you don't think about breathing, you just breathe? It's like that."

Yevhen shook his head in disbelief. "But magic doesn't work that way. It requires will, yes, but also structure. You need mana as fuel, elemental alignment to shape it, the language of Celestial to give it form and purpose. These aren't arbitrary rules—they're fundamental laws of how magic interacts with reality!"

"Maybe I'm using something else," Mira suggested.

"Like what?"

"I don't know. That's why I'm asking you."

---

The breakthrough came from an unlikely source: Professor Aldrich's youngest daughter, who wasn't even a student yet. She was visiting the academy and happened to observe one of Mira's demonstrations.

"She's doing it backwards," the girl said matter-of-factly.

The assembled professors turned to look at her.

"What do you mean, dear?" Aldrich asked.

"Everyone else takes magic from inside themselves and pushes it out into the world. She's pulling magic from the world into herself, and then letting it go where it wants to go."

The simplicity of the observation stunned them all into silence.

Master Yevhen was the first to recover. "That's... theoretically possible, but it would require being completely empty of magic yourself. Any internal mana would interfere with the flow. And you'd have no control over it—the magic would simply pass through you randomly."

"Unless," Aldrich said slowly, "you weren't trying to control it at all. Unless you were simply... directing it. Asking it, as she said."

They turned to look at Mira, who was nodding enthusiastically.

"Yes! That's exactly it! I'm not making the magic do anything. I'm just sort of... showing it where I want it to go, and it goes there."

"But that would mean," Yevhen said, his voice filled with awe, "that you're not actually casting spells at all. You're communicating directly with magic itself. Not using it as a tool, but collaborating with it as a partner."

"Which would explain why she can perform Master-level spells without training," Aldrich added. "She's not constrained by technique or tradition. She's not limited by her own power because she's not using her own power."

Mira smiled. "So I'm not broken?"

"Broken?" Aldrich laughed, and it was a sound of pure wonder. "My dear girl, you're not broken. You're something entirely new. You're the first true Conduit we've ever encountered—a person who doesn't possess magic, but who magic flows through freely. You're not a mage at all."

"Then what am I?"

Master Yevhen looked at her with something approaching reverence. "You're a conversation. A bridge between magic and the world. And I suspect you're going to change everything we think we know about how magic works."

Mira considered this, then grinned. "Does this mean I can stay at the academy?"

"Stay?" Aldrich shook his head in amazement. "Miss Mira, I suspect that very soon, the academy will be studying you."

samples.prompt: There is an ancient Hittite saying "What problem that isn't dealt with will come back.". The sea people as the ancient Bronze Age people have called them are back and are advancing to the Eastern Mediterranean, where they collapsed civilizations 3000 years ago.
samples.output:
# The Return

Dr. Sarah Chen stood on the deck of the research vessel *Poseidon's Gate*, staring at the Mediterranean horizon with growing unease. The satellite data didn't lie, even if every rational part of her mind screamed that it should. Something was moving beneath the waters—something vast, organized, and unmistakably purposeful.

"They're calling it an unprecedented migration pattern," her colleague Marcus said, joining her at the rail. His voice carried the hollow tone of someone trying to convince himself of a comfortable lie. "Mass movement of... something. The oceanographers can't explain it."

Sarah didn't respond immediately. Instead, she pulled out her tablet and scrolled through the images again: sonar readings showing formations that moved with disturbing coordination, underwater structures that appeared and disappeared, and most troubling of all, the archaeological sites along the coast that had begun exhibiting strange activity. Sites that had been dormant for three millennia.

The Hittite tablets had warned them. She'd translated the cuneiform herself six months ago, part of a collection recently excavated near ancient Hattusa. Among the administrative records and royal decrees, one phrase had appeared with unusual frequency: "What problem that isn't dealt with will come back." At the time, she'd assumed it was merely ancient wisdom, perhaps relating to political rivals or economic difficulties.

Now she knew better.

The Sea Peoples—that mysterious confederation of maritime raiders who had brought the Bronze Age civilizations to their knees around 1200 BCE—hadn't simply disappeared into history. They had withdrawn. Retreated. Waited.

The first signs had been subtle. Fishing vessels reporting strange encounters in the deep waters between Cyprus and the Turkish coast. Ancient harbors experiencing unusual tidal patterns. Then came the discoveries: bronze weapons washing ashore, their metallurgy matching Late Bronze Age composition perfectly, yet showing no signs of three thousand years of corrosion. Ships' instruments failing in specific maritime corridors. And finally, three weeks ago, the sighting.

A Greek naval patrol had encountered vessels off the coast of Rhodes. Not modern ships, but craft that resembled ancient Mediterranean warships—yet moved with impossible speed and maneuverability. The crew had managed to capture footage before their electronics failed. The images were grainy, but Sarah had studied them for hours. The ships bore designs consistent with Late Bronze Age construction, adorned with symbols matching those found in Egyptian reliefs depicting the Sea Peoples' invasions.

The international community had been slow to react, hampered by disbelief and bureaucratic inertia. How could anyone take seriously the notion that ancient raiders had returned? It violated every principle of rational thought. Yet the evidence mounted daily. Coastal communities in Turkey reported sightings of armed warriors in archaic armor. Archaeological sites in Syria and Lebanon showed signs of recent activity—not looting, but something more deliberate, as if someone was reclaiming what had once been theirs.

Sarah's research had led her to a disturbing hypothesis. The Sea Peoples' original invasion hadn't been merely a migration or raid—it had been a response to something. The Bronze Age collapse involved multiple factors: climate change, economic disruption, political instability. But what if the Sea Peoples themselves had been displaced by something else? What if they had been driven from wherever they'd originated, and now, whatever had pushed them out before was pushing them back?

"The Turkish coast guard is evacuating Antalya," Marcus said, interrupting her thoughts. "They're not saying why officially, but the rumors are spreading. People are talking about ancient warriors rising from the sea."

"Not rising," Sarah corrected quietly. "Returning. There's a difference."

She thought about the pattern of the original invasions. The Sea Peoples had struck the Hittite Empire, attacked Egypt multiple times, destroyed cities throughout the Levant and Anatolia, and contributed to the collapse of Mycenaean Greece. They had been unstoppable, overwhelming the greatest military powers of their age. The Bronze Age world had never recovered; it had taken centuries for new civilizations to emerge from the ashes.

What would they do to the modern world?

The question haunted her. Modern militaries possessed overwhelming technological superiority, of course. But the reports suggested something beyond simple ancient warriors with bronze weapons. Ships that moved without visible propulsion. Warriors who appeared and disappeared. Coastal defense systems failing without explanation. It was as if the Sea Peoples existed partially outside conventional reality, as if their long absence had changed them into something more than human raiders.

Her tablet chimed with a new alert. Another archaeological site had gone active—this time Ugarit, the ancient Syrian port city destroyed during the original invasions. Seismic sensors detected movement in the ruins. Thermal imaging showed heat signatures consistent with human activity, hundreds of them, in a site that should have been abandoned.

Sarah pulled up a map, marking all the locations showing activity. The pattern was clear: the Sea Peoples were retracing their original invasion routes, reoccupying their former strongholds. They were preparing for something.

"We need to go to Hattusa," she said suddenly. "The Hittite capital. If the ancient texts contain warnings, there might be more information we've missed."

"Sarah, Turkey is closing its borders. The entire Eastern Mediterranean is in crisis mode."

"Exactly why we need to go. The Hittites fought the Sea Peoples. They documented the invasions before their civilization fell. If there's any record of how to deal with this—how to actually deal with it, not just survive it—it'll be there."

Marcus looked at her with a mixture of concern and understanding. "You really believe the old saying, don't you? That they're back because we never truly dealt with them?"

"I believe," Sarah said slowly, watching the darkening waters, "that history doesn't repeat, but it echoes. The Bronze Age world tried to fight the Sea Peoples with military force alone. It wasn't enough. Every civilization that faced them fell. Maybe the Hittites understood something the others didn't. Maybe that's why their warnings survived."

As if in response to her words, the ship's instruments flickered. In the distance, barely visible in the gathering dusk, shapes moved across the water. Not modern vessels. Something else entirely.

The Sea Peoples were returning to the Eastern Mediterranean, and this time, humanity would have to find what the ancients never did: not just the strength to fight them, but the wisdom to truly deal with them.

samples.prompt: "Stop."Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it- I just knew.
samples.output:
# Not Human

"Stop." Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."

The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it—I just knew.

The movement was the first giveaway. No person turns their head quite like that, with such mechanical precision, as if the neck were mounted on ball bearings rather than vertebrae and muscle. The thing that looked like a middle-aged woman in a floral dress completed the rotation a fraction too far, maybe ten degrees past what human anatomy would comfortably allow.

"I'm sorry?" it said, and even its voice carried that same uncanny quality. The words were perfectly enunciated, the pitch and tone exactly what you'd expect from a woman of her apparent age, but there was something missing. Some indefinable quality that makes a voice human rather than simply vocal.

We were standing in the parking lot of a rest stop off Interstate 40, somewhere in the desolate stretch between Albuquerque and Amarillo. It was that dead hour just before dawn when the world feels suspended between night and day, when your mind plays tricks and exhaustion makes reality feel negotiable. We'd been driving for fourteen hours straight, trading off every few hours, racing to reach our father's bedside before it was too late.

The woman—the thing—had approached us as we filled the tank, asking if we knew how to get to Tucumcari. A reasonable question. A normal interaction. Except Sam had frozen the moment he'd seen her, his hand gripping my arm with surprising strength.

"We can't help you," Sam said now, his voice steady but quiet. "You should move along."

I found myself studying the thing more carefully. In the sodium vapor lights of the rest stop, its skin had an odd quality, too smooth, too uniform. Like a wax figure or a CGI character that had almost, but not quite, cleared the uncanny valley. Its eyes didn't quite track right when it looked between Sam and me—there was a microsecond delay, as if it had to consciously remember to shift its gaze rather than simply doing so naturally.

"I'm just looking for directions," it said, and now I could hear what Sam had noticed immediately. The breathing was wrong. It paused to breathe between sentences, yes, but the breath itself made no sound. No intake of air, no subtle whistle of oxygen through nostrils. Just silence, and then words.

"Tucumcari is east," I heard myself say, pointing down the highway. "About an hour from here."

Sam shot me a look that could have melted steel, but I couldn't help myself. Some instinct told me that being rude to this thing, whatever it was, would be a terrible mistake.

"Thank you," it said, and smiled. The smile was worst of all. Every tooth was visible, arranged in a perfect arc, and the expression held for exactly three seconds before dropping away like a curtain falling. No lingering warmth, no gradual fade. Just there, then not there.

It turned and walked toward a sedan parked near the rest stop building. The gait was wrong too—too regular, like a metronome, each step exactly the same length and duration as the last. Humans don't walk like that. We're asymmetrical creatures, favoring one leg slightly, adjusting constantly for minor variations in the ground. This thing moved like it was on rails.

We watched it get into the car. The interior light didn't come on when it opened the door.

"Get in the truck," Sam said. "Now."

We climbed into our father's old F-150, and Sam started the engine with shaking hands. He pulled out of the rest stop faster than necessary, gravel spraying from the tires.

"What the hell was that?" I asked once we were back on the highway, the rest stop's lights fading behind us.

"I don't know," Sam admitted. "But did you see its shadow?"

I hadn't. I'd been too focused on the thing itself.

"It fell wrong," Sam continued. "The angle didn't match the light source. And when it breathed—it didn't breathe, Jess. Its chest didn't move at all."

"Why didn't you say something? Why just tell it to move along?"

"Because I didn't know what it would do if we called it out directly." Sam's knuckles were white on the steering wheel. "Did you notice how it reacted when I said it wasn't human? It didn't deny it. Didn't act confused or offended. It just... adjusted. Like it was recalculating its approach."

We drove in silence for a while, watching the sky lighten gradually in the east. The landscape around us was empty—just scrubland and the occasional lonely building. I kept checking the rearview mirror, half-expecting to see headlights following us, but the road behind remained dark.

"Dad told me something once," Sam said eventually. "Back when I was in high school and you were still in middle school. He said that sometimes, late at night on these long highways, you see things that aren't quite right. Things that look human but aren't. He said his father told him the same thing, and his father before that."

"You think it's real? Like, a family legend that's actually true?"

"I think we just met something that wasn't human, and it was pretending to be. Whether it's what Dad warned me about or something else entirely, I don't know." He glanced at me. "But I know what I saw. And I know you saw it too."

He was right. Whatever that thing had been, it wasn't a person. It was something else, something that had learned to mimic humanity but couldn't quite perfect the performance. The thought of it out there, approaching other travelers at other rest stops, made my skin crawl.

We reached the hospital in Amarillo just as full daylight broke. Dad was still alive, still conscious, and we sat with him through that long day. I wanted to ask him about what Sam had mentioned, about the things that pretend to be human on lonely highways. But he looked so frail, so diminished by the cancer, that I couldn't bring myself to burden him with questions about the inexplicable.

Some things, I suppose, are meant to remain mysteries. But I know one thing for certain: I'll never stop at that rest stop again. And I'll never forget the way that thing smiled at us, too perfect and too empty, before walking away into the dark.

samples.prompt: You're writing a horror novel, and the events in the book start happening in real life.
samples.output:
# The Bleeding Manuscript

I should have stopped writing when the cat disappeared.

It was a small detail, really—just a throwaway line in Chapter Three where I'd written that the protagonist's neighbor's tabby had gone missing, another unexplained disappearance in the cursed town of Millbrook Falls. I'd added it for atmosphere, a minor note of wrongness before the real horror began.

Then Mrs. Chen from 4B knocked on my door, her eyes red-rimmed, asking if I'd seen Whiskers.

"He never stays out overnight," she said, wringing her hands. "Never. Not in eight years."

I told her I hadn't seen him, which was true. I closed the door and stood there for a long moment, staring at my laptop on the kitchen table where my manuscript glowed on the screen. Just a coincidence, I told myself. Cats go missing all the time.

I'd been working on "The Hollowing" for six months, determined to break out of the midlist thriller category and make a name for myself in horror. My agent had been enthusiastic about the premise: a small town where people didn't just disappear—they were erased, unmade, their existence slowly bleeding out of reality until even memories of them faded like old photographs left in the sun.

The story centered on Sarah Winters, a journalist who returns to her hometown to investigate after her sister vanishes. But Millbrook Falls isn't just losing people—it's losing itself, buildings fading into empty lots, streets leading nowhere, the town slowly being consumed by something hungry and patient and utterly incomprehensible.

I'd been proud of it. The prose was tight, the atmosphere suffocating, the horror existential and creeping. My beta readers had called it my best work yet.

That was before the wrongness started seeping into my own life.

After Mrs. Chen's visit, I tried to write, but the words wouldn't come. I kept thinking about Whiskers, about the casual cruelty of that throwaway line. I'd killed that cat with a keystroke—or rather, I'd made it disappear. In my story, no one ever found out what happened to the missing. They were just gone, and eventually, they were forgotten.

I highlighted the sentence about the cat and pressed delete.

Nothing happened, of course. Mrs. Chen's cat was still missing. The universe doesn't work that way. Cause and effect can't flow backward from fiction into reality.

Except the next morning, Whiskers was sitting on Mrs. Chen's doormat, meowing to be let in.

She knocked on my door again, this time with tears of joy, holding the cat like a baby. "He just came back! Like nothing happened! Oh, I'm so relieved."

I smiled and congratulated her and closed the door with shaking hands.

That's when I should have stopped. Deleted the entire manuscript, thrown my laptop into the river, found a new career. But I'm a writer, and writers are curious creatures, even when curiosity becomes dangerous.

I opened the manuscript and searched for my protagonist's name: Sarah Winters.

Then I opened Facebook and searched for the same name.

There were dozens, of course. It's not an uncommon name. But one of them—the third result—made my blood run cold. She was a journalist, thirty-two years old, living in a small town in upstate New York. Her profile picture showed a woman with dark hair and tired eyes, the same features I'd imagined while writing.

Her most recent post was from two days ago: "Heading home to Millbrook to check on some things. Been too long."

Millbrook. Not Millbrook Falls, but close enough to make my hands tremble as I scrolled through her photos. There—a picture from three years ago, two women with their arms around each other, the caption reading "Miss you every day, sis."

The other woman's face was blurred, like someone had smudged it with a thumb. All the comments asked about her, asking who she was. Sarah had responded to none of them.

I slammed the laptop shut and backed away from it like it might bite.

This wasn't possible. Correlation isn't causation. There are small towns called Millbrook all over the country. Journalists named Sarah Winters are probably common. The blurred face in the photo could be a technical glitch, nothing more.

But I knew. Deep in that primitive part of the brain that still believes in curses and evil eyes and words with power, I knew.

My story was happening. Or maybe it had always been happening, and I was just transcribing it, a cosmic stenographer recording horrors I couldn't possibly have invented. Maybe all fiction works this way—maybe every story ever told is true somewhere, somewhen, in some configuration of reality we can't perceive.

Or maybe I'd done something worse. Maybe in reaching for that perfect horror story, I'd reached too far, touched something that shouldn't be touched, and now it was using me as a doorway.

I didn't write for three days. Didn't open the laptop, didn't think about the story. I went to my day job at the bookstore, came home, watched mindless television, and tried to pretend I was normal.

On the fourth day, I got an email from my agent.

"Hey! Haven't heard from you in a while. How's the manuscript coming? Publisher is getting antsy for the full draft. They're really excited about this one—think it could be your breakout. Let me know!"

I stared at the email. The publisher was excited. They wanted the full draft. This could be my breakout, the book that finally made my career, that let me quit the bookstore and write full-time.

All I had to do was keep writing. Keep making it real.

My fingers hovered over the keyboard.

In my story, Sarah Winters discovers the truth too late. She learns that Millbrook Falls is being consumed by something that feeds on existence itself, something that was summoned accidentally by a writer who lived in the town a hundred years ago—a writer who thought he was just making up stories.

She learns that the only way to stop it is to stop writing. To break the connection.

But she also learns that by then, it's already too late. The story has momentum. It will finish itself, with or without the writer.

I opened my laptop and stared at the manuscript. Fifty thousand words written. Fifty thousand more to go.

My fingers touched the keys.

Outside, the streetlight flickered and went dark.

samples.prompt: You doze off while stargazing only to awake to a now starless night sky. You look around and see dots of light floating around. They appear to be connecting to one another, forming lines. You are now in the presence of the Constellations.
samples.output:
# When Stars Walk

The grass was still damp from the afternoon rain when I spread my blanket in the clearing. Above me, the sky had transformed into a canvas of impossible darkness, the kind you only find miles away from any city. Stars scattered across that void like someone had taken a handful of diamonds and thrown them carelessly upward. I'd driven three hours to escape the light pollution, to remember what the universe actually looked like.

I must have been watching Orion's Belt when my eyelids grew heavy. The rhythm of crickets became a lullaby, and the cool September air wrapped around me like a familiar embrace. Sleep came gently, the way it does when you're perfectly comfortable and perfectly at peace.

When I opened my eyes, something was wrong.

The sky was black. Not the rich, deep black punctuated by starlight that I'd fallen asleep under, but an absolute void—an emptiness so complete it made my chest tighten with instinctive fear. For a moment, I wondered if I'd gone blind, but I could see the trees at the edge of the clearing, dark silhouettes against that terrible nothing.

Then I saw the lights.

They floated around me like fireflies, but brighter, more purposeful. Dozens of them, perhaps hundreds, drifting through the air at various heights. Some hovered just above the grass. Others hung suspended twenty feet up. Each one pulsed with a soft, steady glow—white, blue, red, gold. They moved slowly, deliberately, as if searching for something.

I sat up, my blanket sliding off my shoulders. My breath caught as one of the lights drifted close enough to touch, passing inches from my face. It radiated warmth, and in its glow, I could see my own hand, pale and trembling.

"Don't be afraid," a voice said.

I spun around. Standing at the edge of my blanket was a figure made entirely of light—not solid, but not quite transparent either. It was as if someone had drawn a human form using luminous thread, leaving gaps and spaces where the darkness showed through. The figure was tall, with broad shoulders and a bearing that suggested strength. Seven bright points of light formed its core, connected by glowing lines.

"Orion?" The name escaped my lips before I could think.

The figure inclined its head. "I am called by many names. The Hunter. The Warrior. Al-Jabbar. But yes, Orion will do."

Around me, the floating lights began to move with greater urgency. They sought each other out, connecting with thin beams of radiance. I watched in amazement as they formed shapes—a great bear taking form to my left, a swan spreading its wings overhead, a scorpion assembling itself near the tree line, its tail curving menacingly upward.

"What's happening?" I asked, finding my voice. "Where are the stars?"

"We are the stars," Orion said, gesturing to the beings taking shape around us. "Or rather, we are what you've always made us to be. For thousands of years, you've looked up at us and seen stories. You've connected our dots, drawn your lines, given us names and myths and meaning. Tonight, we've come down to meet the ones who dreamed us into being."

A figure approached from behind Orion—smaller, more delicate, with stars forming the shape of a crown. "Cassiopeia," she said, introducing herself with a voice like wind chimes. "We've watched you for so long. All of you. Generation after generation, lying on your backs, staring up, wondering."

More constellations gathered. I recognized some—Ursa Major, Leo, Gemini with its twin forms standing side by side. Others were unfamiliar, perhaps from parts of the sky I'd never learned or from cultures whose stories I'd never heard. They formed a circle around me, not threatening, but curious.

"Why now?" I asked. "Why tonight?"

The Scorpion spoke, its voice a low rumble. "Because you're forgetting. Your cities grow brighter, your skies grow emptier. Fewer and fewer of you look up anymore. Fewer still see us as anything more than distant gas and nuclear fire. The stories are fading."

"We're being reduced to coordinates and catalog numbers," added a constellation I didn't recognize, its form suggesting a ship with billowing sails. "We're becoming data points instead of dreams."

Orion knelt beside me, and despite being made of light, his presence felt solid, real. "We don't blame you. Your species is young, and you're learning so much, so fast. You've learned what we really are—that I'm not a hunter but hundreds of stars, most of them hundreds of light-years apart, aligned only by accident of perspective from your small world."

"But something is lost in that knowledge," Cassiopeia continued. "The truth of what we are and the truth of what we mean—both can exist together. Both should exist together."

I looked around at them, these impossible beings, these living stories. "What do you want from me?"
