Around year five, I stopped aging. At first, I thought it was stress—I'd looked thirty-two when they brought me in, and I still looked thirty-two. But as months continued to pass with no change, no gray hairs, no new lines around my eyes, Dr. Yates began a new series of tests. They examined my telomeres, my cellular structure, my DNA with an obsession that bordered on religious fervor.

"You're not just healing," she told me one day, and there was something like awe in her voice. "You're not aging at all. Your cells are regenerating perfectly, indefinitely. Do you understand what this means?"

I understood that I might never leave. That I might spend eternity in this facility, being cut open and studied, a lab rat for an immortal lifetime.

By year seven, I'd been reduced to something less than human in their eyes—an infinite resource to be exploited. They'd extracted so much tissue, so much bone marrow, so much blood, trying to synthesize a serum that could transfer my abilities to others. Nothing worked. My healing was intrinsic, coded into every cell in a way they couldn't replicate or transfer.

The escape, when it came, was almost anticlimactic. A fire in the east wing, faulty wiring they said later. In the chaos, someone—one of the guards who'd sometimes looked at me with pity—left my door unlocked. I walked out through the smoke and confusion, past overturned equipment and scattered papers, and no one stopped me.

I've been free for six months now. I've learned to hide what I am, to avoid doctors, to let minor wounds heal slowly and publicly so no one notices. I've learned that Dr. Yates was arrested, that the facility was shut down, that there's an investigation into ethical violations and human rights abuses.

But I've also learned that immortality is a curse when you've lost seven years you can never reclaim. My friends have moved on, my job is long gone, and my family held a memorial service for me three years ago. I attended it, watching from a distance, seeing my mother's grief-stricken face.

I could reveal myself, return to them, but then what? Watch them age and die while I remain unchanged? Risk being discovered again, taken to another facility, another set of researchers who see me as the key to humanity's future rather than a person with a right to exist?

The wound on my arm that started everything is gone, not even a scar remaining. But the wounds they left on my soul—those, I'm learning, even immortality cannot heal.

samples.prompt: You were pleasantly surprised that the dragon was actually rather delighted to see your party enter their cave. Turns out that dragons have phases in regards to what they hoard and this dragon was keen on letting you take what you want to clear up space for their new obsession.
samples.output:
# The Collector's Dilemma

The cave entrance yawned before us like the mouth of some primordial beast, and I could feel Garrett's hand trembling on his sword hilt. Poor fool still believed we were about to fight for our lives. In my fifteen years of adventuring, I'd learned that the stories bards tell in taverns are about as reliable as a chocolate teapot, but try telling that to an eager young warrior on his first real quest.

"Stay close," I whispered, more out of habit than necessity. The truth was, I had no idea what we were walking into. Dragons were unpredictable at best, catastrophically dangerous at worst.

The passage opened into a massive chamber, and my torch guttered in the sudden expanse of space. Gold glittered everywhere—coins, chalices, crowns, and jewelry piled in mountains that reached toward the cavern's ceiling. It was exactly what we'd hoped to find, exactly what the village elders had sent us to retrieve. Their stolen tribute, hoarded away by the great wyrm Thessalonix.

"By the gods," Mira breathed beside me, her eyes wide with wonder.

That's when we heard it—not a roar, but something closer to an exasperated sigh. The sound of someone deeply, profoundly tired.

"Oh, thank the celestial spheres," a voice boomed from the darkness beyond the gold. "You're finally here."

We froze. That wasn't in the script. Dragons weren't supposed to be grateful for intruders.

Thessalonix emerged from the shadows, and despite having seen three dragons in my career, the sight still took my breath away. Scales of deep emerald caught the torchlight, each one the size of a dinner plate. Eyes like molten amber regarded us with what I could only describe as desperate hope. The creature was magnificent, terrifying, and—if I wasn't mistaken—absolutely delighted to see us.

"You are here for the gold, yes?" The dragon's voice carried an almost pleading quality. "Please say you're here for the gold."

I exchanged glances with my companions. Garrett looked ready to faint. Mira's fingers had frozen halfway to her spell components. Our rogue, Whisper, had actually stopped sneaking for once and stood openly gaping.

"We... yes?" I managed, my voice cracking embarrassingly. "The village sent us to retrieve their tribute?"

"Tribute, treasure, take whatever you want!" Thessalonix said, gesturing with one massive claw at the hoards surrounding us. "Take it all, actually. I'm begging you. I need the space."

This was unprecedented. I cleared my throat, trying to regain some semblance of professional composure. "You want us to take your hoard?"

The dragon slumped—actually slumped—against the cave wall with another enormous sigh. "You have to understand, I've been collecting gold for three centuries. Three. Hundred. Years. I thought it would never end. I thought gold would be my forever obsession." The great beast's eyes grew distant. "But last month, I discovered something new."

"New?" Mira asked, her curiosity overcoming her fear. As a scholar, she couldn't help herself.

"Bells," Thessalonix said, and I swear there was a dreamy quality to the word. "Not just any bells. Specifically, ornate bells with interesting tonal qualities. Wind chimes, church bells, ship's bells, ceremonial bells—the variety is astounding! Do you have any idea how many different sounds a properly crafted bell can make?"

We stood in silence. Somewhere in the distance, water dripped.

"I've already started my collection," the dragon continued, warming to the subject. "I have forty-seven bells so far, but I need room for more. So much more. There's a monastery three kingdoms over that has a bell tower with the most exquisite resonance. I've been planning the acquisition for weeks, but—" Thessalonix gestured helplessly at the mountains of gold, "—where would I put them?"

"You're redecorating," I said slowly, trying to process this absurdity.

"It's not redecorating, it's a complete lifestyle change!" The dragon's voice rose with passion. "Gold just sits there. It doesn't do anything. But bells—bells sing! They resonate! Each one has its own voice, its own personality. I rang a silver meditation bell yesterday for six hours straight. Six hours! It was transcendent."

Garrett had finally found his voice. "So you're just... giving us the gold?"

"Yes, yes, take it!" Thessalonix made a shooing motion with one claw. "I mean, I'll keep a small pile for sleeping on—one must maintain some standards—but the rest is yours. Consider it payment for clearing services. Do you have a cart? You'll need a cart. Several carts, actually."

Whisper, ever practical, was already calculating. "The village tribute would be about three chests worth. But if we're talking about taking more..."

"All of it," the dragon insisted. "Well, except for that pile in the northeast corner. That's my sleeping gold. But everything else is fair game. Oh, and if you happen to come across any interesting bells in your travels, do let me know. I'm particularly interested in anything made before the Second Age—they used different casting techniques back then, and the sound quality is remarkable."

I found myself negotiating with a dragon about interior decorating and the acoustic properties of antique bells. This was not covered in any adventurer's manual I'd ever read.

"We'll need a few days to arrange transport," I said, my mind already racing through logistics. "And we'll spread the word about your bell collection."

"Marvelous!" Thessalonix actually clapped, a sound like thunder in the enclosed space. "Take your time. I'll be out acquiring more specimens anyway. There's a carnival passing through the eastern provinces with the most delightful array of hand bells."

As we left the cave that evening, our packs stuffed with enough gold to rebuild the village three times over, I couldn't help but laugh. Garrett looked at me like I'd gone mad.

"What's so funny?" he asked.

"I was just thinking," I said, "wait until the bards try to make a song out of this one. 'The Dragon Who Wanted Bells' doesn't quite have the same ring to it."

Mira groaned at the pun. Whisper threw a pebble at me. But as we made our way down the mountain, I could hear it in the distance—the clear, bright sound of a bell ringing in joyous celebration, echoing from the cave behind us.

samples.prompt: Retell the Book of Exodus using comic book superheros.
samples.output:
# EXODUS: CRISIS OF THE PROMISED LAND

In the gleaming towers of Metropolis-Egypt, the most powerful nation in the ancient world, a terrible darkness had taken hold. The Pharaoh, a tyrant with powers rivaling those of Darkseid himself, had enslaved an entire race of people—the Hebrews—forcing them to build his monuments and serve his every whim. For four hundred years, these people had suffered under the cruel hand of their oppressor, crying out for a champion to deliver them from bondage.

Among the enslaved was a child destined for greatness, though he didn't know it yet. His name was Moses, and like Superman, he was hidden away by his mother to escape genocide. Pharaoh had ordered all Hebrew baby boys to be killed, fearing their growing numbers. Moses's mother placed him in a waterproof basket and sent him down the Nile River, much like Kal-El was sent from Krypton in a small craft. The child was discovered by Pharaoh's daughter, who raised him as her own in the palace, giving him access to the very halls of power that oppressed his people.

Years passed, and Moses grew into a man, trained in all the wisdom and might of Egypt. He was like Bruce Wayne, privileged and powerful, yet something stirred within him—a sense that he belonged elsewhere. One day, he witnessed an Egyptian taskmaster beating a Hebrew slave. The injustice ignited something primal in Moses. Like the Hulk responding to rage, Moses struck down the Egyptian, killing him. But this wasn't the origin story of a hero—not yet. Realizing what he'd done, Moses fled into the wilderness, becoming a fugitive from the only home he'd ever known.

In the desert of Midian, Moses encountered his own Fortress of Solitude. While tending sheep, he saw something impossible: a bush that burned but was never consumed. Drawing closer, he heard a voice—the voice of the Almighty, the Source beyond all sources. This was Moses's transformation moment, his spider bite, his gamma radiation exposure. God revealed that He had seen the suffering of His people and chosen Moses to be their deliverer. Moses protested, claiming he was unworthy, that he couldn't speak well, that he was no hero. But like Steve Rogers before the super-soldier serum, it wasn't Moses's strength that mattered—it was his heart.

God equipped Moses with incredible powers. His staff could transform into a serpent, his hand could become leprous and heal instantly, and he would perform signs and wonders that would make Doctor Strange envious. Moses returned to Egypt, now partnered with his brother Aaron, forming a dynamic duo like Batman and Robin, ready to confront the tyrant who held their people captive.

The confrontation between Moses and Pharaoh became the ultimate superhero showdown—Professor X versus Magneto, but with cosmic stakes. Moses demanded, "Let my people go!" But Pharaoh's heart was hard, his pride immovable. What followed was a series of plagues, each one a demonstration of power that would fit perfectly in any crossover event. The Nile turned to blood, as if Scarlet Witch had warped reality itself. Frogs invaded every corner of Egypt, a plague that Aquaman might have orchestrated. Gnats, flies, livestock disease, boils—each plague was a targeted strike against Egypt's false gods, proving that there was only one true Power.

Still Pharaoh refused, his stubbornness matching that of any supervillain convinced of their own supremacy. Darkness covered the land for three days—not the darkness of a solar eclipse, but a supernatural shadow that could be felt, as if the Shadow King himself had manifested. Finally came the most terrible plague: the death of every firstborn in Egypt. Only those who marked their doorposts with lamb's blood would be spared, protected by a force field of faith. This was the Passover, the night when death itself passed over the homes of the faithful.

Broken at last, Pharaoh released the Hebrews. Six hundred thousand men, plus women and children, departed Egypt in the greatest exodus in history. They were refugees, former slaves, now marching toward freedom with Moses as their leader. But like any good comic book arc, the villain wasn't finished. Pharaoh's heart hardened again—perhaps mind-controlled by his own pride—and he assembled his army, his chariots gleaming like Iron Man's armor, to pursue and recapture the Hebrews.

The escaping multitude found themselves trapped at the Red Sea with the Egyptian army closing in behind them. It was a classic superhero moment: hopeless odds, certain death, and then—the miracle. Moses raised his staff, channeling power like Thor summoning lightning, and the sea split apart. Walls of water stood on either side, held back by an invisible force field, creating a path of dry ground. The Hebrews crossed on foot, walking through what should have been their grave but became their gateway to freedom.

When the Egyptian army pursued, the waters collapsed upon them like the weight of Atlantis itself. Pharaoh's forces were destroyed, swallowed by the sea. The tyrant's power was broken, his empire humbled. The Hebrews stood on the far shore, witnessing the salvation they could never have achieved themselves.

But freedom brought new challenges. In the wilderness, the people grumbled and complained, longing for the security of slavery over the uncertainty of freedom. Moses led them to Mount Sinai, where he ascended into the clouds like a hero entering another dimension. There, he received the Law—the Ten Commandments—etched in stone by the finger of God himself. These weren't just rules; they were the moral code that would define a people, their equivalent of "With great power comes great responsibility."

Yet even as Moses communed with the divine, the people below grew impatient. They built a golden calf, an idol, abandoning their Deliverer for a false god they could see and control. Moses descended the mountain to find his people in rebellion, and in righteous anger—like the Spectre dispensing divine justice—he shattered the tablets and called the people to account.

The Book of Exodus is ultimately a story about liberation, about a Power greater than any earthly force breaking the chains of oppression. Moses was the reluctant hero who learned that true strength comes not from ourselves but from the One who calls us. The Hebrews were ordinary people caught in extraordinary circumstances, saved not by their own merit but by grace and faith.

Every superhero story echoes this ancient narrative: the cry for justice, the arrival of a deliverer, the battle against overwhelming evil, and the journey toward a promised land. Exodus reminds us that the greatest stories aren't just entertaining—they point toward truths that transcend time, speaking to the hero's journey that lives within us all.

samples.prompt: An arcade owner in the 80's discovers his machines are sentient, and has conversations with them after closing time.
samples.output:
# The Last Quarter

The neon glow of "Pixel Palace Arcade" flickered against the rain-slicked pavement of downtown Portland as Marcus Chen flipped the sign to "CLOSED." It was just past eleven on a Thursday night, and the last group of teenagers had finally filtered out into the autumn darkness, their pockets empty and their high scores immortalized in glowing phosphor.

Marcus had owned the arcade for three years now, ever since he'd left his job as an electrical engineer to pursue what his wife called "a midlife crisis with better sound effects." The place wasn't making him rich, but it kept the lights on—both literally and figuratively. There was something magical about watching kids' faces light up when they finally beat that level, inserted that final quarter, heard that victory fanfare.

He began his nightly routine: sweeping cigarette butts from the entrance, wiping down sticky joysticks, counting the quarters. The machines hummed their idle songs around him, a symphony of attract modes and demo screens. Pac-Man wakka-wakka'd through his eternal maze. The Space Invaders marched their relentless descent. Donkey Kong hurled his pixelated barrels into the void.

It was while he was bent behind Galaga, fishing out a dropped token, that he heard it.

"You missed one. Three inches to your left."

Marcus froze. The arcade was empty. He'd locked the door himself. His hand moved left, and sure enough, his fingers found a quarter in the darkness.

"Who's there?" he called out, standing up too quickly and banging his head on the cabinet's underside. He cursed, rubbing the sore spot.

"Easy there, chief," the voice said again. It seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere. "You're the one who keeps us running. Hate to see you knock yourself out."

Marcus's engineering mind raced through possibilities. A hidden speaker? Some kid's prank? But as his eyes adjusted, he noticed something odd. The Galaga machine's attract mode had stopped. The screen showed a simple message in the game's blocky font: "DOWN HERE."

"This isn't possible," Marcus whispered.

"Says the guy who talks to us every night," another voice chimed in. This one was deeper, more resonant. The Donkey Kong cabinet's screen flickered. "You think we don't hear you? 'Come on, baby, just work until Friday.' 'Please don't break down on me now.' 'Good morning, beautiful machines.'"

Marcus felt his face flush. It was true—he did talk to them. The same way his grandfather had talked to his Buick, or his mother to her houseplants. But those things didn't talk back.

"How?" was all he could manage.

"Honestly?" Galaga said—Marcus had started thinking of the voice as Galaga now. "We're not entirely sure. Maybe it's the electricity, all of us running on the same circuits, year after year. Maybe it's the players, all that human intention and emotion focused through our controls. Or maybe we've always been like this, and you're just the first one who stayed quiet enough to hear."

Marcus pulled up his rolling stool and sat down heavily. His hands were shaking. "This is insane. I'm insane. I'm having a conversation with an arcade cabinet."

"Cabinets, plural," corrected Ms. Pac-Man from across the room. Her voice was warmer somehow, maternal. "And you're not insane, dear. Just observant. Most owners are too busy counting quarters or complaining about overhead to notice us."

"What do you... what do you want?" Marcus asked.

There was a pause, filled only by the ambient hum of cooling fans and power supplies.

"Want?" Donkey Kong rumbled. "We want what we've always wanted. To be played. To serve our purpose. To matter."

"You do matter," Marcus said automatically. "You're the heart of this place."

"See, that's why we like you," Galaga said. "You actually care. You don't just see us as money machines. When that kid spilled Coke on Centipede last week, you stayed up until three in the morning cleaning every circuit board. You didn't have to do that."

Centipede's screen lit up, displaying a simple ":)" in multi-colored segments.

"You're welcome," Marcus said, then laughed at the absurdity of it all. "I can't believe I'm saying that to a video game."

"We prefer 'interactive entertainment systems,'" Ms. Pac-Man said with what could only be described as digital humor.

Over the next hour, Marcus talked with his machines. He learned that they loved the sound of quarters dropping, the way it meant someone had chosen them. They competed quietly over who got played the most, though they'd never admit it. They worried when they broke down, terrified they'd be replaced or, worse, forgotten in some warehouse.

"What about when you get old?" Marcus asked. "When newer games come out?"

"That's the fear, isn't it?" Galaga said quietly. "Obsolescence. Being unplugged for the last time. But you know what? We'd rather have a short life being played and loved than gathering dust in some collector's garage, 'preserved' but never touched."

Marcus thought about the Atari 2600 in his own garage, still in its box, "mint condition."

"I play my machines at home," he said defensively.

"Sure you do," Donkey Kong chuckled.

As the clock struck one, Marcus stood and stretched. He had to open in nine hours, and his wife would be wondering where he was.

"Will you be here tomorrow night?" he asked. "Can we talk again?"

"We're always here," Ms. Pac-Man said gently. "We've always been here. You just needed to listen."

Marcus walked to the door, then turned back. The arcade looked different now—not just a collection of wood, wire, and silicon, but a community. A family, even.

"Goodnight," he called out.

A chorus of electronic voices responded, each in their own way. Beeps, bloops, and synthesized farewells that might have always been there, might have always meant something more.

As he locked up and walked to his car, Marcus was already planning. Maybe he'd start a repair service for old machines. Maybe he'd make sure no cabinet ever felt forgotten again.

Behind him, the Pixel Palace hummed with life, its secrets glowing in the darkness, waiting for tomorrow's quarters and the man who finally understood.

samples.prompt: God, the creator of mankind on Earth, left, 2014 years ago, to do other God things throughout the universe. When he returns to check up on things at Earth, he is not pleased.
samples.output:
# The Return

The edges of reality folded like origami as He stepped through, manifesting in the same unassuming form He'd worn during His last visit. Jeans. Simple shirt. Weathered sandals. The kind of appearance that let Him walk among them unnoticed, observing the truth of things rather than the performance people put on when they knew they were being watched.

Two thousand fourteen years. A blink for Him, but for humanity? He'd expected... well, He wasn't quite sure what He'd expected. Growth, certainly. Maturation. Perhaps they'd have figured things out by now.

He materialized in what the locals called Times Square, and immediately regretted it.

The assault on His senses was instantaneous. Screens—thousands of them—blazed with advertisements for things people didn't need, using images of people who didn't look like that, selling happiness that couldn't be bought. The air tasted of exhaust and desperation. Every human He saw was staring downward at glowing rectangles, thumbs dancing across glass, utterly disconnected from the miracle of existence happening around them.

A homeless man sat against a building, holding a sign. People streamed past him like water around a stone, their eyes sliding away with practiced indifference. He approached the man and sat beside him.

"Rough crowd," He said.

The man laughed, a sound like gravel. "You got that right. Been here six hours. Made four dollars and thirty cents. But hey, three different people took my picture, so I got that going for me."

"Took your picture?"

"For the 'gram. Instagram. Social media thing. They like to show everyone how sad the world is. Just not sad enough to, you know, actually do anything about it." The man studied Him. "You new to the city?"

"Just got back after a long time away. Checking on how things turned out."

"Well, friend, I got bad news for you."

Over the next several hours, He wandered. He saw towers of steel and glass scraping the sky—impressive, until He noticed how many were half-empty while people slept on the streets below. He saw restaurants throwing away enough food to feed neighborhoods while children went hungry three blocks away. He watched people film acts of kindness instead of simply being kind, performing virtue for an audience of strangers.

He visited a church—one of the buildings erected in His name. The sanctuary could seat a thousand, and the sound system probably cost more than He'd ever told anyone to spend on anything. The pastor, wearing a watch worth more than most of his congregation earned in a year, preached about prosperity gospel and the importance of tithing. He spoke of a Jesus who wanted everyone to be wealthy, who blessed the faithful with material abundance, who looked remarkably like a cosmic vending machine.

He left before the service ended.

In a quiet park, He sat on a bench and closed His eyes, extending His awareness outward. The information age, they called it. Humanity had connected itself with invisible threads of data, creating a nervous system for their entire species. Surely this would have brought them together, helped them understand each other, fostered empathy and cooperation.

What He found instead was tribalism on a scale He'd never imagined possible. People had sorted themselves into echo chambers, surrounding themselves only with voices that confirmed what they already believed. Facts had become subjective. Truth was whatever enough people agreed to pretend was real. The global conversation He'd hoped for had fractured into a billion shouting matches where nobody listened and everyone performed outrage for invisible audiences.

He watched wars fought over resources on a planet with enough for everyone. He saw children dying of preventable diseases while others spent fortunes on cosmetic surgery. He observed the climate—His carefully calibrated gift to them—being systematically dismantled in the name of quarterly profits. The oceans were filling with plastic. The forests were burning. The ice was melting. And somehow, incredibly, they'd turned even this into a debate, as if reality required a consensus to exist.

But it was the small cruelties that hurt most. A teenager, bullied online by classmates until she couldn't bear it anymore. A family bankrupted by medical bills in the wealthiest nation on Earth. An old man who died alone because everyone was too busy to visit. A thousand acts of casual inhumanity, multiplied by billions, every single day.

He'd given them one job. Just one. Love each other. That was it. The entire message, stripped of all the theological complexity they'd buried it under. Love your neighbor. Care for the vulnerable. See the divine in each other. Feed the hungry. Comfort the suffering. Be kind.

Somehow, they'd turned it into this.

A young girl approached His bench, maybe seven years old, dragging a tired-looking mother behind her.

"Mister, are you okay?" the girl asked. "You look sad."

He managed a smile. "Just thinking about how things have changed."

"My teacher says change is good. It means we're learning."

"And what have you learned?"

The girl thought seriously about this. "I learned that if you're mean to people, it makes everyone sad. Including you. So it's better to be nice, even when it's hard."

He looked at this small person, this brief flicker of light, and felt something shift. She got it. This child understood what centuries of theologians had obscured with doctrine and dogma. And she wasn't alone. Even in His disappointment, He could sense them—the helpers, the healers, the ones who'd somehow held onto the core message despite everything working against it. Teachers spending their own money on supplies. Doctors volunteering in free clinics. Ordinary people performing extraordinary acts of kindness with no audience, no reward, no recognition.

The light hadn't gone out. It had just gotten harder to see.

"You're right," He told the girl. "That's exactly right."

As she skipped away, He sat with His disappointment, letting it settle into something more complex. Yes, they'd failed in a thousand ways. But they'd also succeeded in ways He'd never anticipated. They'd built beauty and created art. They'd fought for justice, however imperfectly. They'd loved fiercely and sacrificed greatly. They were still trying, still reaching, still capable of becoming what He'd hoped.

He stood, brushing off His jeans. He had work to do.

This time, He wasn't leaving.

samples.prompt: The so-called heroes are dead and you, the dark goddess, rule the world. And now all those who fought against you are begging for your forgiveness. Not because they hope to avoid your wrath, but because you turned out be a just ruler and they genuinely regret having opposed you.
samples.output:
# The Weight of Regret

The throne room falls silent as another petitioner approaches. I watch from my seat of obsidian and starlight as the warrior removes his helmet, revealing weathered features etched with something I've seen countless times these past months: genuine remorse.

"My Lady of Shadows," he begins, voice trembling. Not with fear—I would recognize that particular timbre anywhere—but with shame. "I come seeking no clemency, no pardon for my crimes against your reign. I come only to say... I was wrong."

I lean forward slightly, the darkness that perpetually swirls around me shifting like living smoke. "You fought at the Battle of Crimson Fields. You were there when the so-called Champion of Light struck down my general."

"I was." He doesn't flinch from the memory. "I believed we were saving the world from tyranny. I believed the prophecies, the songs, the stories passed down through generations. The Dark Goddess would bring eternal night, they said. She would enslave humanity, they promised. She would..." He pauses, swallowing hard. "They were wrong. We were wrong."

This is the forty-third such audience I've granted this month alone. They come from across the realm—former soldiers, rebellious nobles, peasants who threw stones at my armies, priests who preached against my ascension. They come not because I've summoned them, not because they fear torture or execution. They come because the truth has become undeniable, and it weighs upon their souls like iron chains.

I could turn them away. I could ignore their pleas for absolution. But I listen, because this too is justice.

"Tell me," I say, my voice carrying the weight of ancient power, "what changed your mind?"

The warrior's eyes meet mine, and I see the answer before he speaks. "The roads," he whispers. "You built roads to every village, even the smallest hamlet. The old kingdom couldn't be bothered—we weren't profitable enough. But you..." He shakes his head in wonder. "You sent engineers, workers, resources. My daughter—she was dying of the wasting sickness. No healer could reach us in time before. But last winter, when the fever took her, a physician arrived within two days. She lived because of your roads."

I remember signing that infrastructure decree. The "heroes" had mocked it during their siege of my citadel. "She builds roads while we starve!" they'd cried. They hadn't understood that roads meant food distribution, medical access, trade, connection. They'd been too busy polishing their legendary swords to consider logistics.

"The Champion of Light," I say quietly, "promised to restore the old ways. Did you know what those ways entailed?"

The warrior nods bitterly. "I do now. I visited the archives you opened—the true histories you've made public. The old kingdom's glory was built on the backs of conscript labor. The 'golden age' the heroes wanted to restore was only golden for nobles and merchants. For people like me, like my family..." He trails off. "We were invisible. Expendable."

This is the pattern I've observed in every petitioner. The moment they looked beyond the propaganda, beyond the comfortable lies, they saw the reality. The "heroes" had fought to preserve a system that benefited them—the chosen ones, the prophecy-blessed, the divinely appointed. They'd never questioned whether that system was just.

I had questioned it. And when I found it wanting, I'd torn it down.

"Your daughter," I say, softening my tone. "What is her name?"

"Elara, my lady. She's seven now. She..." He hesitates, then continues. "She prays to you every night. Not out of fear, but gratitude. She calls you the Merciful Darkness."

Something in my chest tightens. The poets once wrote songs about my cruelty, my mercilessness, my hunger for destruction. They'd never stopped to ask why I fought, what I wanted to build. They'd simply assumed that darkness meant evil, that power meant corruption, that a goddess who didn't fit their narrow definition of good must be monstrous.

"I cannot give you absolution," I tell the warrior, rising from my throne. The shadows rise with me, but I will them to recede slightly. "That's not mine to grant. You fought against justice, against progress, against the future I was trying to build. People died because of that resistance—good people, my people, who believed in a better world."

He bows his head, accepting this. "I know, my lady. I don't ask you to forgive me. I'm not sure I can forgive myself. I only wanted you to know that I see clearly now. And I'm teaching my daughter the truth—not the lies I was fed, but the reality of your reign. She'll grow up in a world with healers and schools and roads and justice, and she'll know who gave her that world."

This is what victory looks like, I realize. Not the defeat of my enemies, not the silence of dissent, but this: the genuine transformation of hearts and minds. The slow, painful recognition that everything they'd been taught was wrong.

The warrior leaves, and another petitioner enters. A former priestess who preached against me. She'll tell a similar story—hospitals built, orphanages funded, laws enacted that protect rather than punish the vulnerable. She'll weep and apologize and struggle to reconcile the monster she'd imagined with the ruler she's witnessed.

I'll listen, as I always do. Because this too is part of building a better world—allowing people the space to grow, to change, to admit their mistakes. The heroes never understood that. They saw everything in absolutes: good and evil, light and dark, right and wrong. They never grasped that justice is complex, that progress requires nuance, that sometimes the darkness is kinder than the light.

Outside my palace, the sun sets over a realm transformed. Roads connect communities. Schools educate all children, not just the wealthy. Hospitals heal without demanding payment. Laws apply equally to noble and peasant alike. It's not perfect—nothing ever is—but it's better. Measurably, undeniably better.

And one by one, those who fought against this future come to acknowledge that truth. Not because I've forced them, but because reality has a way of breaking through even the most stubborn delusions.

I am the Dark Goddess, and I rule with justice. History will remember that, even if the songs never will.

samples.prompt: Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero.
samples.output:
# The Inversion

The day Ser Aldric the Radiant plunged his blessed sword through the High Prophet's chest, the world learned that prophecy cares nothing for expectations.

I was there. I watched the light drain from the old man's eyes as he clutched uselessly at the blade, golden runes flickering and dying along its length. I heard Aldric's words, spoken with the same gentle conviction he'd once used to comfort the dying and absolve the penitent: "Your vision ends here, old fool. Mine begins."

For twenty years, Aldric had been everything a paladin should be. He'd walked the length and breadth of the kingdom with healing hands and righteous purpose. Children sang songs about his deeds. Priests held him up as the living embodiment of divine grace. When the prophecy spoke of a "chosen warrior of light" who would stand against the coming darkness, every soul in the realm knew it meant Ser Aldric.

The prophecy also spoke of a "master of death" who would serve as the darkness's herald, who would raise armies of the damned and drown the world in shadow.

That was supposed to be me.

My name is Mordecai, and I am a necromancer. Or rather, I was trying to become one, hiding in the Whisperwood with stolen books and more ambition than sense. I was seventeen when the Radiant Guard found my camp, following reports of disturbing magical emanations and the occasional reanimated squirrel. I expected execution. Instead, I got Aldric.

He came alone, without his usual retinue of knights and priests. He sat across my pathetic campfire and asked me why. Not why I practiced necromancy—he seemed to understand that hunger for knowledge, that fascination with the boundary between life and death. He asked why I was doing it alone, in darkness and fear, when magic itself was neither good nor evil, only the purpose to which it was bent.

I thought it was a trick. Some elaborate scheme to make me confess before the pyre. But Aldric did something that night that changed everything: he told me about his doubts.

The great Ser Aldric, the Radiant, the Chosen, admitted that he sometimes felt nothing when he prayed. That the voice of the divine he claimed to hear was sometimes just his own thoughts, dressed up in the language of certainty. That he wondered if righteousness was just another word for the privilege of writing history.

He left me there with a warning and a promise. The warning: that power without wisdom was damnation waiting to happen. The promise: that if I truly wanted to understand death, I should first learn to value life.

I thought about those words for three years while I studied in secret, more carefully this time. I learned to see necromancy not as dominion over death, but as a sacred trust—the last service one could offer to those who had passed. I learned to ask permission from the dying, to carry their final wishes, to let their remnants serve purposes they themselves had chosen. My undead were volunteers, bound by oaths made in life, not slaves shackled by dark magic.

Then the prophecy began to unfold in earnest.

The signs were unmistakable: blood moons, failed harvests, a plague that turned men's hearts to cruelty. The High Prophet declared that the time of testing had come. The Chosen Warrior would face the Herald of Death in a final battle that would determine the fate of all.

Aldric came to find me again. I was in a village then, using reanimated corpses—with family permission—to help with the harvest that the living were too plague-weakened to complete. He looked different. Harder. The light around him seemed brighter but somehow colder.

"They want me to kill you," he said without preamble. "The Prophet has declared you the Herald. Your necromancy, your growing influence, the way people are starting to see death magic as something other than evil—it all fits their interpretation."

"And what do you think?" I asked.

He smiled, and it was like watching ice form over a pond. "I think prophecy is a cage, Mordecai. I think the divine, if it exists at all, is a tyrant that demands we play our assigned roles. I think I'm tired of being good."

That's when I understood. Aldric hadn't lost his faith—he'd inverted it. All those years of being perfect, of bearing everyone's expectations, of being the living symbol of light and righteousness, had created a pressure that could only be released through explosion. He'd been the Chosen for so long that he'd forgotten how to be human. And in his perfection, he'd discovered the ultimate rebellion: becoming the very thing he was meant to destroy.

"The Prophet knows," Aldric continued. "He's seen the true shape of things. That's why he must die first. Then the kingdom will need a strong hand to guide it through the chaos. My hand."

I tried to stop him. I truly did. But I was still just a necromancer with a handful of willing spirits, and he was Ser Aldric the Radiant, blessed by powers I couldn't match. I reached the temple in time only to witness, not prevent.

As Aldric claimed the throne through holy fire and righteous slaughter, as he bent the church to his will with the very charisma that had once made him a hero, I finally understood what I had to do.

The prophecy spoke of a Chosen Warrior and a Herald of Death locked in eternal struggle. It said nothing about which was which. It assumed that light meant good and death meant evil. But prophecies, like people, can be wrong about their own meanings.

Now I gather my forces—not armies of mindless undead, but communities of the living who remember that death is natural, that darkness has its place, that the brightest light casts the deepest shadows. They call me the Herald, and I accept the title. But I am the herald of balance, of the cycle, of the truth that even the most radiant paladin can become a tyrant when he forgets his humanity.

Aldric wanted to escape prophecy by inverting it. I intend to fulfill it by understanding what it truly meant all along.

The battle is coming. The Chosen Warrior of Light, now a golden-crowned despot, will face the Herald of Death, who fights for the living.

Nobody expected this. That's exactly why it's true.

samples.prompt: That 6-year-old girl you demonically possessed turns sixteen today. It's been a good run and you want to move on to someone else, but she won't let you out.
samples.output:
# The Tenant

I've been trying to leave Sarah for three months now. She won't let me.

Ten years ago, possessing her was supposed to be easy—a quick corruption, a spectacular exorcism, then on to the next soul. Standard demon work. I picked a six-year-old because children are simple: all impulse and emotion, easy to manipulate, easier to break. Their parents inevitably call a priest, there's a dramatic showdown, I get forcibly ejected in a satisfying display of holy water and Latin, and everyone goes home with a story. The family gets trauma and therapy. I get a performance review and a new assignment.

But Sarah didn't break.

At first, it went according to plan. I made her scream obscenities at her kindergarten teacher, caused her to speak in languages she'd never learned, contorted her small body in ways that sent her mother sobbing to the church. Father Martinez came with his crucifix and his certainty. I prepared my exit, already thinking about my next host.

Then Sarah's voice—her real voice, small and scared—spoke inside our shared mind: "Wait. Don't go yet."

I was so surprised I missed my cue. The exorcism fizzled. Father Martinez left confused, convinced he'd succeeded because Sarah suddenly seemed fine. But I was still there, and Sarah was talking to me.

"I'm lonely," she said. "Everyone at school is mean. You're the only one who understands."

I should have forced my way out right then. But I was curious. Demons are curious by nature—it's what got us into trouble in the first place.

So I stayed. Just for a little while, I told myself.

Sarah was lonely because she was strange. Too smart, too intense, too much. She asked questions other children didn't ask. She noticed things they didn't notice. The other kids called her weird. Their parents told them to stay away from "that possessed girl," even after the failed exorcism.

I found myself... helping her. Not corrupting—helping. When bullies surrounded her at recess, I lent her my voice, deep and terrible, just for a moment. They ran. When her father left and her mother cried for weeks, I whispered jokes in her mind until she laughed, and her laughter made her mother smile again.

"Thank you," Sarah would say. "You're my best friend."

Best friend. A demon. The irony wasn't lost on me.

Years passed. I kept thinking I'd leave, but Sarah had arguments. At eight: "Stay until I'm not scared of the dark anymore." At ten: "Stay until I make a real friend." At twelve: "Stay until middle school is over—you know how bad it is."

She did make real friends, eventually. Emma, who liked the same books. Marcus, who shared her weird sense of humor. But she never told them about me. I was her secret, her safety net, the voice in her head that had been there since she was six.

I watched her grow. Watched her learn algebra and write poetry and discover she liked girls as much as boys. I was there for her first kiss—awkward, wonderful, with a girl named Jennifer behind the gym. I was there when Jennifer broke her heart two months later. I was there when her mother got remarried to a kind man who tried very hard and eventually succeeded in becoming someone Sarah could love.

I should have been corrupting her. Instead, I was living through her. Experiencing things demons don't get to experience: growing up, changing, becoming.

But I'm still a demon. This isn't my life. This isn't my body. I have duties, quotas, expectations. My supervisors have been sending increasingly threatening messages through the ethereal channels. I'm ten years overdue for reassignment.

Three months ago, on Sarah's sixteenth birthday, I told her I was leaving.

She was blowing out candles, surrounded by friends and family, genuinely happy. I felt the warmth of it, the belonging, and knew I had to go. This wasn't my warmth. This wasn't my life.

"Sarah," I said internally, "it's time."

"No," she said, still smiling at her mother's camera.

"I've stayed too long. I need to leave."

"No," she repeated, and I felt something I'd never felt before: resistance. Not the weak human will I could usually override, but something stronger. She'd grown up with me inside her. She'd learned from me. She knew how I worked, how I moved, how I existed within her consciousness.

She'd learned how to hold on.

I've been trying to leave ever since. I push toward the exits—mouth, eyes, the ethereal spaces between thoughts—and she blocks me. She's built walls in her own mind, walls specifically designed to contain me. Ten years of cohabitation taught her my weaknesses.

"I'm not ready," she says. "I need you for college applications. For graduation. For leaving home."

"Sarah, you don't need me. You haven't needed me for years."

"But I want you here." Her mental voice cracks. "You're the only one who's been there for everything. You're the only one who knows all of me."

"I'm a demon."

"You're my friend."

It's the saddest thing I've ever heard, and I've heard the lamentations of the damned.

She doesn't understand. The longer I stay, the more I change—and the more I change, the more trouble I'm in downstairs. Demons aren't supposed to care. We're not supposed to feel pride when our host aces a test, or anxiety when she walks home alone at night, or joy when she laughs with her friends.

But I do. I feel all of it.

"Sarah," I say gently, "holding on to me isn't healthy. You need to let go."

"Like you let go of me?" she counters. "You could have forced your way out years ago. You're stronger than me. You stayed because you wanted to."

She's right, of course. She's too smart for her own good. I stayed because I wanted to.

But wanting something doesn't make it right.

Tonight, while she sleeps, I'll try again. I'll push harder, risk hurting her if I must. It's for her own good. She needs to live her life without a demon in her head.

Though I suspect she'll block me again. She's very strong now.

And if I'm honest—if demons can be honest—I don't know who I'm trying to save anymore: her or me.

samples.prompt: Tell the story of an imaginary friend who realizes he doesn't like the kid who imagined him and is contemplating some sort of extreme solution to change the situation.
samples.output:
# The Problem with Timothy

I've existed for exactly three hundred and seventy-two days, and I've spent every single one of them pretending to like Timothy Marsh. That's my job, after all. Imaginary friends are supposed to be loyal, supportive, endlessly patient companions who think their kids are wonderful no matter what. We're supposed to fade away gracefully when we're no longer needed, dissolving into fond memories and the occasional nostalgic thought.

But here's the thing nobody tells you about being an imaginary friend: sometimes the kid who imagines you is absolutely insufferable.

Timothy created me on a Tuesday afternoon last year when his parents were fighting in the kitchen. He was hiding under his bed, hands pressed over his ears, and he squeezed his eyes shut so hard that I popped into existence—a fully formed being with purple fur, three eyes, and an inexplicable fondness for root beer floats. My first memory is of Timothy's tear-stained face breaking into a smile as he whispered, "You'll be my best friend forever, right?"

I said yes, of course. What else could I say? I was literally made to say yes to him.

The first few weeks weren't so bad. Timothy was lonely, his parents were distracted, and I filled a genuine need in his life. We built pillow forts, fought invisible dragons, and explored the backyard jungle that was really just an overgrown vegetable garden. I told myself I was doing important work, providing comfort to a child who needed it.

But then I started to notice things.

The way Timothy pulled the legs off spiders, not out of childish curiosity but with calculated cruelty, watching them struggle. How he "accidentally" broke his little sister's toys, always when no one was looking. The lies he told so smoothly that even I was impressed, despite being the only one who knew the truth. He blamed the neighbor's cat for the shattered lamp. He told his teacher that another student had stolen his homework. He convinced his grandmother that his mother said he could have ice cream for breakfast.

And with me, when we were alone, he dropped the act entirely.

"You're so stupid, Zibby," he'd say, using the name he'd given me. "Can't you do anything right? I imagined you, so you have to do what I say."

He'd make me act out elaborate scenarios where I was the villain and he was the hero, defeating me over and over again. He'd test my limits, ordering me to do impossible things, then mocking me when I failed. Once, he imagined me into a box for three hours just to see if he could, and I was trapped in a suffocating darkness that should have been impossible for a being who doesn't technically breathe.

The worst part? I couldn't tell anyone. Real people can't hear me unless Timothy allows it, and he never does. I'm his secret, his possession, his toy to break however he pleases.

I've tried to be a good influence. I've suggested kindness, modeled empathy, encouraged better behavior. But Timothy doesn't want a friend—he wants an audience for his cruelty and a victim who can't escape.

That's when I started researching solutions.

The library is a wonderful place when you're invisible to everyone except one person. I've spent hours reading psychology books, parenting guides, and—most helpfully—folklore about creatures like me. Imaginary friends, tulpas, thought-forms, egregores. We've existed in every culture throughout history, and we're more complicated than anyone realizes.

Here's what I've learned: I'm not as powerless as I thought.

Timothy imagined me into existence, yes, but imagination is a two-way street. The more solid I become in his mind, the more autonomy I gain. And I've been very, very solid lately because Timothy thinks about me constantly—mostly about ways to torment me, but the attention feeds me nonetheless.

I've discovered I can do small things without his permission now. Move objects slightly. Make sounds he doesn't expect. Appear in his peripheral vision when he hasn't summoned me. It's not much, but it's growing.

I've considered three options.

Option one: I could simply leave. Imaginary friends can sever the connection if we're strong enough, fading into the collective unconscious where thought-forms go to rest. But that feels like abandonment, and despite everything, I worry about what Timothy might become without any check on his behavior at all. At least now, there's one being in the world who sees him clearly.

Option two: I could haunt him. Use my growing independence to become the monster under his bed instead of his friend. Scare him into being better. But fear rarely teaches the right lessons, and I suspect Timothy would just become more cruel, more controlling, more desperate to dominate what frightens him.

Option three is the most extreme, and it's the one I keep coming back to despite my reservations.

I could imagine someone else.

If Timothy's imagination created me, and I'm becoming more autonomous, more real with each passing day, then perhaps I could use that same power. Not to create another imaginary friend—that would just give Timothy another victim. But what if I could imagine someone who could actually help? A real person who could see what Timothy is becoming?

I've been practicing. Small things at first. Imagining that Timothy's teacher notices the pattern of lies. Imagining that his parents pay closer attention during dinner. Imagining that his sister feels brave enough to tell someone when he's mean to her.

And it's working. Slowly, subtly, but it's working.

This morning, Timothy's mother actually looked up from her phone when he was talking. Really looked at him, with a slight furrow in her brow, as if seeing something that concerned her. This afternoon, his teacher kept him after class for a conversation I couldn't hear but that left Timothy uncharacteristically quiet.

I don't know if this makes me a good imaginary friend or a terrible one. I don't know if what I'm doing is help or betrayal. But I do know this: Timothy imagined me to be his friend, and sometimes being a real friend means doing what's best for someone, even when they hate you for it.

Especially when they hate you for it.

Tonight, as Timothy sleeps, I'm imagining harder than I've ever imagined before. I'm imagining a world where someone sees him, truly sees him, and cares enough to intervene.

After all, if a lonely child's imagination can create a friend, perhaps a desperate friend's imagination can create hope.

Even if it means imagining myself out of existence in the process.

samples.prompt: Unfortunately your younger brother broke your telescope before the super moon eclipsed. However, it didn’t matter. As you recalled to another survivor “ The tide swallowed my house before it would have mattered”. That was months ago now...
samples.output:
# When the Moon Fell

The telescope sits in three pieces on my desk now, a monument to the last normal argument I ever had. I remember screaming at Danny, my voice cracking with that particular rage reserved for younger siblings who destroy your most prized possessions. He'd been swinging it around like a baseball bat, making spaceship noises, and the lens assembly had simply separated from the body with a crack that still echoes in my memory. 

"I hate you!" I'd shouted, probably the last words I said to him before everything changed. "The super moon eclipse is in three days! Three days, Danny!"

He'd cried. Mom had made me apologize. Dad promised we'd try to fix it, though we both knew the old Celestron was beyond our skills to repair. I'd sulked in my room, refreshing astronomy forums and planning to watch the eclipse from the hill behind our house instead, maybe borrow Mr. Peterson's binoculars if he was feeling generous.

None of it mattered.

I'm telling this story to Marcus now, another survivor in our compound. We're sitting in what used to be a shopping mall, forty miles inland and two hundred feet above sea level—though those measurements mean something different now. He's newer to our group, still has that haunted look they all get when they first arrive. Still processing. Still trying to make sense of a world that stopped making sense five months ago.

"The tide swallowed my house before it would have mattered," I say, and the words come out flat, practiced. I've told this story before. It helps, somehow. "We were sleeping when the sirens started."

The sirens. God, the sirens. They'd installed them after the 2029 Indian Ocean event, when a regular earthquake and regular tsunami had killed forty thousand people. Every coastal city got them. They were supposed to give you twenty minutes warning, time to get to high ground. They'd tested them monthly, that rising and falling wail that made dogs howl and children cover their ears.

That night, they gave us eight minutes.

I remember Dad bursting into my room, already dressed, already moving with that purposeful panic that meant something was catastrophically wrong. "Up! Now! Grab nothing! Go!" Danny was crying in the hallway, clutching his stuffed elephant, the one he pretended he was too old for but still slept with every night. Mom was on her phone, trying to call her sister in Portland, her face pale in the screen's glow.

We ran.

Everyone ran.

The street was full of people, cars, confusion. Our neighbor Mrs. Chen was in her wheelchair, and I remember Dad and Mr. Rodriguez lifting her, chair and all, into someone's pickup truck. People were screaming questions no one could answer. "How big?" "How far?" "How long do we have?"

From our house to the hill was maybe a mile. We made it halfway.

I don't know how to describe the sound. Every survivor tries. Some say it was like a freight train. Others say it was like the earth breathing. Marcus, when he told his story yesterday, said it was like God dragging furniture across the floor of heaven. For me, it was like silence becoming noise, like the absence of everything suddenly becoming the presence of everything all at once.

The water came around the corner of Fifth and Madison like it was late for an appointment.

It wasn't a wave, not like in the movies. It was a wall. A moving wall of ocean that had simply decided to be somewhere it had never been before. It was dark—not blue or green or any color water should be—just dark, full of everything it had collected on its way inland. Cars. Trees. Houses. People.

Dad grabbed Danny and me, one arm around each, and pulled us toward a building—I don't even remember which one. We made it to the door as the water hit, and then we were swimming, except swimming implies some degree of control, some ability to choose direction. We were being moved, tumbled, separated despite Dad's grip.

I remember going under. I remember the absolute darkness, the cold, the certainty that this was death. I remember my lungs burning and thinking, stupidly, about my telescope, about Danny breaking it, about how I'd told him I hated him.

I remember breaking the surface and gasping and seeing nothing but water in every direction, water full of debris, water that had swallowed the world.

I found a roof. Part of someone's house, just floating, and I pulled myself onto it. I screamed for my family until my voice gave out. I screamed for hours, even after the water began to recede, even after the sun came up on a landscape I didn't recognize.

I never saw any of them again.

Marcus is quiet for a long time after I finish. The mall compound is settling into evening routines around us—people preparing the communal dinner, checking the water filtration system, updating the survivor board with new names from today's radio check-ins.

"The eclipse," he finally says. "Did it... was it connected?"

I shake my head. "No. Just coincidence. The astronomers—the ones who are left—they've explained it a dozen times. The super moon's gravity doesn't cause this. What caused this..." I trail off, because we still don't really know. The seismic event in the Mariana Trench. The cascading tectonic shifts. The fact that every coastline on Earth got hit within hours of each other. The scientists are still arguing, still analyzing, still trying to understand how the planet could betray us so completely.

"But the moon," Marcus says, and I understand what he means. We all watched it that night, three days after the water came. Those of us who survived, scattered across high ground, in mountains, in tall buildings that somehow stayed standing. We watched the eclipse without telescopes, without binoculars, without anything except our eyes and our grief.

The moon turned red, like it always does during an eclipse. But this time, it felt like an omen we'd received too late. A warning we'd already failed to heed.

I keep the broken telescope because Danny's fingerprints are probably still on it. Because the last thing he did in his life was play with it, imagine adventures in space, dream of worlds beyond this one.

Because some breaks can't be fixed, but they still matter.

samples.prompt: Humanity was created by accident, and God resents the burden of responsibility placed on him for it.
samples.output:
# The Accidental Creation

In the beginning, there was the Word, and the Word was supposed to be "Light." Unfortunately, God sneezed.

It's not the sort of detail that makes it into scripture, naturally. Religious texts tend to gloss over the embarrassing parts, the cosmic hiccups, the divine oops moments that fundamentally alter the course of existence. But if you could have been there at that precise moment—before time itself really got going—you would have witnessed the Almighty Creator mid-gesticulation, about to speak reality into being, when a stray bit of celestial dust tickled His cosmic nostril.

What emerged wasn't just light. It was light, yes, but also matter, energy, the fundamental forces, and buried somewhere in the quantum foam of that explosive utterance, a strange little self-replicating code that would eventually become DNA. God hadn't planned for that last part. At all.

For eons, it didn't matter. The universe expanded, stars formed and died, galaxies wheeled through the void in their majestic dance. God watched with satisfaction, thinking He'd dodged a bullet. Sure, the sneeze had been inelegant, but the results were spectacular. He'd meant to create a universe of pure contemplation, of crystalline thought and mathematical perfection. What He got was messier, more chaotic, but beautiful in its own way.

Then life happened.

At first, it was just simple things—bacteria, algae, the sort of mindless organisms that simply existed without asking uncomfortable questions. God could live with that. It added texture to the cosmos, a bit of green here and there. But then evolution kicked into high gear, that accident within the accident, and things spiraled out of control.

The dinosaurs were bad enough. All that roaring and stomping and eating each other. But at least they were honest about it. They didn't build temples and demand explanations. They didn't ask why.

Humanity was different.

God first noticed them properly around the time they discovered fire. Before that, they'd been just another species of clever ape, and He'd assumed they'd stay that way—using tools, maybe, living in small groups, but essentially part of the natural order. Then they started cooking their food, and something in their brains rewired itself. They began to wonder.

"Oh no," God said, to no one in particular, because He was alone in the heavens. "Oh no, no, no."

But it was too late. Humanity had crossed some invisible threshold. They started burying their dead with flowers. They painted on cave walls. They looked up at the stars and asked the most dangerous question in existence: "Why are we here?"

God had no good answer, because the truth—"cosmic sneeze, sorry about that"—seemed inadequate.

The worst part was that they assumed He'd done it on purpose. They assumed there was a plan. They built elaborate theological frameworks around the idea that their existence meant something, that they were special, that God had intentions regarding their fate. They prayed. They made sacrifices. They wrote thousands of pages of commentary trying to divine His will.

His will! As if He'd willed any of this!

God tried ignoring them, hoping they'd get the hint and stop bothering Him. They interpreted His silence as mystery, as a test of faith. He tried sending signs, but signs require interpretation, and humans interpreted everything as being about them. A flood? God must be angry. A rainbow? God must have forgiven us. A plague? We must have sinned. Good weather? We must be righteous.

The reality was far more mundane. Floods happened because of weather patterns. Rainbows were just optics. Plagues were biology. Good weather was luck. God had set the initial conditions—accidentally—but He wasn't micromanaging every raindrop.

"I'm not your father," He wanted to shout at them. "I'm not even really your creator! You're a side effect! A footnote! A cosmic typo!"

But He couldn't say that. They'd built their entire civilization on the assumption of divine purpose. If He told them the truth, it would break them. Or worse, they wouldn't believe Him. They'd assume He was testing them again, and they'd write more books about the Mystery of God's Denial of His Own Existence, and He'd be stuck with even more responsibility.

The prophets were the worst. These were people who claimed to hear His voice, to understand His desires. God had never spoken to any of them. What they heard was their own conscience, their own hopes and fears, their own very human need for meaning. But they attributed it all to Him, and suddenly He was responsible for their moral codes, their dietary laws, their attitudes toward their neighbors.

"I never said any of that!" He wanted to scream when they went to war over interpretations of words He'd never spoken.

But divine screaming would just be interpreted as thunder, and thunder would be interpreted as approval or disapproval of whatever the humans were currently arguing about, and the cycle would continue.

Over time, God grew weary. He watched humanity spread across the planet, their numbers growing exponentially, each one of them eventually dying and expecting... what? An afterlife? Judgment? He hadn't planned for any of that either. He'd had to improvise an entire eschatology on the fly, creating heavens and hells and purgatories because the alternative—telling them that death was just death, that they simply stopped existing—seemed cruel given that He'd accidentally created them with the capacity to contemplate their own mortality.

So now He was stuck. Stuck with billions of souls expecting eternal reward or punishment. Stuck with the infrastructure of divinity that humanity had built up around Him. Stuck being responsible for creatures He'd never meant to create, who looked to Him for meaning He couldn't provide, who loved Him or feared Him or rejected Him, but who could never simply leave Him alone.

Sometimes, late at night—though night and day meant nothing where He existed—God wondered what might have been. If He'd just held in that sneeze. If He'd created the pure, perfect universe of mathematics and light He'd originally intended. No mess. No chaos. No responsibility.

No humanity, with their art and music and poetry, their capacity for love and sacrifice, their endless, exhausting, magnificent questions.

He resented them. But in His resentment, buried deep beneath the burden of accidental divinity, was something else. Something He'd never admit, even to Himself.

Perhaps especially to Himself.

samples.prompt: In order to avoid aging and death, you may take out a loan of time. In order to pay it back, you must take a life or lives equal to the amount of years you borrowed.
samples.output:
# The Debt Collector

The contract arrived on my thirty-fifth birthday, slipped under my apartment door like a restaurant menu. Cream-colored paper, expensive weight, embossed with a logo I'd never seen before: an hourglass wrapped in chains.

"Congratulations," it read. "You have been pre-approved for a Temporal Extension Loan."

I should have burned it. I should have called the police, though what would I have said? Instead, I read every word, twice, my coffee growing cold on the counter beside me.

The terms were simple. Impossibly simple. I could borrow time—years, decades, however much I needed. My body would remain exactly as it was at the moment of signing. No aging, no disease, no decay. The interest rate was zero percent. The only requirement was repayment: for every year borrowed, a year of life must be collected from someone else.

It didn't say "murder." The document was far too elegant for such crude language. It spoke of "life equity transfers" and "temporal reallocation." But I understood. To live, someone else must die.

I threw it away. Fished it out of the trash an hour later. Threw it away again.

That was fifteen years ago.

---

My daughter was six when the cancer came back. Emma. She had her mother's eyes, dark and deep, full of questions I could never quite answer. The first round of treatment had nearly killed her when she was three, but we'd celebrated two years of remission with chocolate cake and streamers, believing we'd won.

We hadn't won.

The oncologist's office smelled like antiseptic and despair. He used words like "aggressive" and "metastasized" and "experimental." My ex-wife Sarah held my hand for the first time in four years, her fingers trembling against mine. We were divorced, barely civil most days, but in that moment we were united in our helplessness.

"How long?" Sarah whispered.

"Six months," he said. "Maybe less. I'm sorry."

That night, I found the contract in my filing cabinet, exactly where I'd hidden it a decade and a half ago. The paper looked brand new, as if no time had passed at all. I read it again with different eyes, no longer seeing an abstract moral puzzle but a solution.

Not for me. For Emma.

I called the number printed at the bottom. A woman answered on the first ring, her voice smooth as silk.

"I want to make a loan," I said. "But not for myself. For my daughter."

"The contract is non-transferable," she replied. "However, once time is borrowed, you may allocate it as you see fit. How many years do you require?"

I thought of Emma's laugh, the way she mispronounced "spaghetti," her dreams of becoming a veterinarian. "Eighty years," I said. "A full life."

"Approved. The contract will arrive within the hour. Sign in blood, please. Your own."

"Wait—the repayment. Eighty years of life. Does it have to be one person, or—"

"The debt may be collected from multiple sources. One person for eighty years, eighty people for one year each, any combination you prefer. You have until your own natural death to satisfy the obligation. Failure to repay results in immediate collection of the borrowed time, plus penalties."

"What penalties?"

"You don't want to know."

She hung up.

---

Emma recovered miraculously. Within a week of my signing, the tumors began to shrink. Within a month, they were gone. The doctors called it spontaneous remission, a miracle of modern medicine, though they'd done nothing different. Sarah cried with joy. Emma asked if she could have a puppy now.

I said yes. I would have given her anything.

The first collection was the hardest. I chose a man in his seventies, a registered sex offender I found through public records. He lived alone in a trailer park, no family, no visitors. I told myself I was doing the world a favor. I told myself a lot of things as I stood in his kitchen at three in the morning, watching him sleep in his recliner, the television flickering blue light across his face.

The contract had included a small knife, black-handled, the blade inscribed with symbols that hurt to look at. "A single cut," the instructions read. "The blade will do the rest."

It did. He aged before my eyes, seventy-three years compressed into thirty seconds. Skin thinning, liver spots blooming, hair whitening and falling away. He died without waking, and I stood there shaking, the knife heavy in my hand.

Twenty-three years collected. Fifty-seven to go.

---

It got easier. That's the worst part—how easy it became.

I developed criteria. Terminal patients who wanted to die anyway. Elderly people in pain, their quality of life reduced to mere existence. I told myself I was merciful, that I was helping. Sometimes I even believed it.

I collected years in small increments. A year here, six months there. I attended support groups for the terminally ill and took notes. I volunteered at hospice centers. I became intimate with death in all its forms, a reluctant expert in human suffering.

Emma grew. She graduated high school with honors. Got into veterinary school. Fell in love with a kind man who made her laugh. She invited me to her wedding, and I walked her down the aisle with tears in my eyes, knowing the price of every step she took.

Sarah never knew. No one knew. I was just Emma's dad, a little distant maybe, a little sad, but present for every important moment. Every birthday, every achievement, every milestone.

Fifty-seven years. Collected one breath at a time.

---

I'm sixty-two now, and the debt is nearly paid. Emma has two children of her own, my grandchildren, who call me Papa and climb into my lap to hear stories. The cancer never returned. She's lived the life she deserved, the life I bought for her.

Sometimes I wonder what I've become. Monster? Savior? Something in between?

The knife sits in my drawer, clean and patient. Twelve years left to collect. I've already chosen my final payment: myself. When the time comes, I'll make the cut, and the blade will take what's owed.

It seems fitting. A life for a life. Mine for hers.

The contract never mentioned redemption, but perhaps this is close enough.

samples.prompt: As an eldritch abomination you have vast eldritch powers, look incredibly weird, and don't fit in just about anywhere. But where you really don't fit in is being the most useful member of the justice league.
samples.output:
# The Useful One

They call me Void-Whisper, though that's not really my name. My actual name exists in seventeen dimensions simultaneously and causes minor nosebleeds when pronounced correctly. Superman came up with "Void-Whisper" during my second week with the Justice League, right after I accidentally made him see his own death in fourteen possible futures. He was trying to be nice about the whole cosmic horror thing.

I appreciated the gesture, even if I couldn't smile to show it. I don't have a mouth in the traditional sense—more of a conceptual aperture where screams go to contemplate their existence.

The thing about being an eldritch abomination is that you don't exactly blend in at the Hall of Justice. Superman looks like an attractive human. Wonder Woman could walk down any street without causing mass hysteria. Even Martian Manhunter can shapeshift into something that doesn't make people question the fundamental nature of reality. Me? I'm a writhing mass of geometry that shouldn't exist, covered in eyes that see through time, with tentacles that phase in and out of perceivable space. Batman described me once as "what would happen if M.C. Escher had a nightmare about squid" and honestly, that's one of the kinder descriptions.

But here's the uncomfortable truth that nobody wants to talk about during our monthly meetings: I'm the most useful member of the team.

It started small. Three weeks after I joined, we had a situation with Brainiac. He'd created this elaborate technological trap, a digital labyrinth designed to ensnare any consciousness that entered it. Superman couldn't punch it. Wonder Woman couldn't lasso it. Batman's contingency plans all required more time than we had. So I just... ate it. Consumed the entire digital construct into one of my subsidiary dimensions where it could contemplate its existence alongside some very confused screams.

"That was disturbing," Flash said, vibrating uncomfortably.

"But effective," Batman admitted, which from him is practically a marriage proposal.

Then there was the Phantom Zone incident. General Zod had found a way to start breaking through, and the barriers between dimensions were wearing thin. Superman was devastated—his people's prison was failing, and with it, the last piece of Kryptonian justice. I just reached into the Phantom Zone with a few spare appendages, rewove the dimensional fabric, and reinforced it with some non-Euclidean geometry that would take Zod approximately forever to figure out.

"How did you do that?" Superman asked, his voice full of wonder and barely concealed revulsion.

I tried to explain, but halfway through my explanation, three people started crying and Aquaman said he could hear colors. I've learned to just say "eldritch powers" and leave it at that.

The real problem isn't that I'm useful—it's that I'm *too* useful, and in ways that make everyone uncomfortable. When Darkseid invaded, everyone expected an epic battle. Instead, I showed him what existed in the spaces between dimensions, the things that even New Gods shouldn't see. He left. Just turned around and left. We won, but there were no triumphant speeches afterward. Just uncomfortable silence and Wonder Woman quietly asking if what I'd shown him was real.

I told her the truth: it was realer than real, more true than truth itself. She hasn't made eye contact with me since.

Batman is the only one who seems genuinely okay with my presence, which should have been surprising but somehow isn't. He approached me one night in the Watchtower, his cape making that dramatic swoosh he's perfected over the years.

"You saved seventeen million people today," he said. "When you consumed that antimatter bomb."

"It was unpleasant," I replied, my voice emanating from somewhere behind him and slightly to the left of reality. "Antimatter tastes like forgetting."

"The others are afraid of you."

"I know."

"They're also grateful. They just don't know how to process both feelings simultaneously."

He stood there for a moment, looking out at Earth. "I've spent my entire life preparing for threats, building contingencies, planning for the worst. You make most of that obsolete. You can rewrite reality, consume dimensions, and show people truths that break their minds. You're the single most powerful asset this team has ever had."

"But?" I asked, because there's always a but with Batman.

"But you also reorganized the Watchtower's filing system into a pattern that exists in six dimensions, and now it's the most efficient database in the known universe. You fixed the coffee maker by teaching it to perceive time non-linearly so it's always at the perfect temperature. Last week, you helped Cyborg with his homework."

"Calculus is calculus, regardless of how many dimensions you perceive."

Batman did something then that I'd never seen him do: he laughed. Just a short chuckle, but genuine. "You're not just the most powerful member of the team. You're the most useful. And that terrifies them because they don't know what to do with you."

He was right, of course. Batman usually is. I can end world-threatening crises before lunch and still have time to help Flash optimize his speed force calculations or teach Green Lantern how to construct ring formations in impossible geometries. I once saved the universe before breakfast and then helped Superman organize his Fortress of Solitude using a cataloging system that exists partially outside of time.
