The Justice League doesn't know what to do with someone who's both cosmically terrifying and genuinely helpful. I don't fit into their narrative of heroes and villains, of epic battles and last-minute saves. I just solve problems, often in ways that make people uncomfortable, and then I do the dishes using tentacles that technically don't exist in this reality.

Last week, during a team meeting, Flash asked if anyone wanted to grab pizza afterward. There was an awkward silence before Wonder Woman said, "Sure, that sounds nice." Another pause. Then Superman, very carefully, asked, "Should we... invite Void-Whisper?"

I was standing right there. I'm always standing right there, even when they can't quite perceive me properly.

"I would like pizza," I said. "Though I should warn you, I experience taste in ways that might disturb you."

We got pizza. I paid. It was the least I could do, being the most useful member of the Justice League and all.

samples.prompt: You've died and find out that the afterlife is merely a character creation process where you gained points in your previous life through good deeds and achievements to spend on stats and perks for your next life.
samples.output:
# The Character Sheet of Souls

The transition from alive to dead wasn't nearly as dramatic as I'd imagined. No tunnel of light, no life flashing before my eyes, no St. Peter at golden gates. Instead, I blinked and found myself sitting in what could only be described as the cosmic equivalent of a DMV waiting room—sterile white walls, uncomfortable chairs, and the faint hum of fluorescent lighting that seemed to emanate from everywhere and nowhere at once.

"Number 847,293,012," a voice called out, somehow both bored and eternal.

I looked down at my hand. Sure enough, a small ticket had materialized there with that exact number printed in neat, black digits. I stood, my legs working perfectly despite the fact that I distinctly remembered dying in a hospital bed, my body ravaged by cancer and age. Here, I felt thirty again. No, better than thirty—I felt like the idea of thirty, unburdened by the reality of it.

The voice had come from a doorway that definitely hadn't been there a moment ago. I walked through it and entered a small office where a being sat behind a desk. They—and "they" felt like the only appropriate pronoun—looked simultaneously like every ethnicity and none, every age and ageless, wearing what might have been a cardigan or might have been robes of starlight. My brain couldn't quite settle on what it was seeing.

"Please, sit," they said, gesturing to a chair that was suddenly much more comfortable than the ones in the waiting room. "I'm sure you have questions."

"Am I... is this..."

"Dead? Yes. Heaven? Hell? Not quite." They pulled out what looked like a manila folder but shimmered with an otherworldly quality. "Think of this more as... an intermission. A character creation screen, if you will. You've completed your previous playthrough, and now it's time to allocate your points for the next one."

I stared at them. "My what?"

They sighed the sigh of someone who had explained this countless times. "Your life—the one you just finished—that was essentially your point-gathering phase. Every good deed, every achievement, every moment of genuine kindness or personal growth earned you points. Now you get to spend them on your next life." They opened the folder, and I saw what looked like my entire existence laid out in neat columns and rows. "You did fairly well, actually. 847,293 points total."

My mind reeled. "So life is just... a game?"

"Life is life," they said with a slight smile. "This is just the administrative side of reincarnation. Someone has to keep the books balanced. Now, shall we review your earnings?"

They began reading through my life like a sports commentator reviewing game footage. "Helped elderly neighbor with groceries consistently for five years—2,300 points. Donated to charity, though you could have given more—1,890 points. Forgave your father before he died despite having every reason not to—that's a big one, 45,000 points right there. Stayed loyal to your spouse through the difficult years—30,000 points. Mentored three young people who went on to make significant positive impacts—15,000 points each. Adopted a rescue dog—5,000 points, plus bonuses for the joy you gave each other."

I felt tears forming, though I wasn't sure if I actually had tear ducts in this form. "I didn't do any of that for points."

"That's exactly why they count," they said gently. "The system rewards genuine compassion, not calculated point-gathering. Though you'd be surprised how many people come through here upset they didn't know about the points beforehand so they could 'optimize their build.'" They shook their head. "Those people usually have very few points to spend."

"What about the bad things I did?"

"Ah, yes. Those don't earn points, obviously, but they don't subtract from your total either. They simply... limit your options in the next life. Create mandatory challenges you'll have to face. Think of them as difficulty modifiers you've locked in." They flipped through a few pages. "You weren't a saint, but you weren't terrible either. Mostly minor selfishness, a few significant regrets, one major betrayal of trust in your twenties that you spent decades trying to make amends for. Standard human stuff, really."

They pulled out what looked like a glowing tablet. "Now, let's talk about what you can afford. Basic stats first: Intelligence, Charisma, Constitution, Wisdom, Luck, and Creativity. Each starts at a baseline of 10 for the average human. You can boost them with your points. Then we have perks—special abilities, advantages, circumstances of birth. Those get expensive."

I looked at the interface they showed me. Intelligence boosts cost 5,000 points per level. Charisma was 4,000. Constitution—basically health and longevity—was 10,000 per level. The perks ranged from "Born into Wealth" (200,000 points) to "Natural Talent: Music" (30,000 points) to "Immunity to Addiction" (50,000 points) to simple things like "Good Hair" (500 points).

"Can I see what I had last time?" I asked.

They showed me. I'd been remarkably average, with most stats at 10 or 11, except for Wisdom, which was a 14, and Luck, which was a 7. I'd had no special perks at all.

"You were playing on hard mode," they said. "And you still managed to accumulate over 800,000 points. That's commendable."

I studied the options, my mind racing with possibilities. I could make myself intelligent, beautiful, talented, healthy. I could buy my way into a wealthy family or guarantee myself extraordinary luck. But as I looked at the prices, I realized something.

"What happens if I don't spend the points?" I asked.

They looked up, surprised. "They roll over into your baseline karma. Make your next life generally... easier. More opportunities, better circumstances, nothing guaranteed but better odds overall. Why?"

I thought about my life. The struggles had been real, but so had the triumphs. The pain had been genuine, but it had taught me empathy. My average intelligence had made me work harder. My poor luck had made me appreciate the good moments.

"I think," I said slowly, "I'd like to put most of it into Wisdom and Compassion. And maybe bump my Constitution up a bit—I'd like to be healthy enough to help people for longer. But otherwise... surprise me."

They smiled, and for the first time, it reached what might have been eyes. "You know, you're going to do very well next time around. Same time, same place, in about nine months?"

I nodded, feeling ready.

The office began to fade.

samples.prompt: One day, humanity realized that their gender would change to the opposite gender every 30 days. Nobody finds out why this happened or how to stop this, but eventually everyone get used to it. Depict their everyday lives.
samples.output:
# The Thirty-Day Cycle

Maya checked her calendar app out of habit, though she didn't really need to. The familiar tingling sensation in her fingertips told her everything she needed to know—tomorrow would be a transition day. She'd be male again by Thursday morning. The realization brought neither excitement nor dread, just the mild annoyance of having to reschedule her haircut appointment for next week when her hair would be shorter again.

It had been seven years since the Shift began, as people called it. Seven years since that inexplicable Tuesday when every human on Earth went to sleep one gender and woke up another. The panic, the chaos, the conspiracy theories—all of that felt like ancient history now. Humanity had proven remarkably adaptable, as it always did when given no other choice.

"Don't forget you're picking up Jordan from school today," her husband Chen called from the kitchen. He was currently female, about two weeks into his cycle. They'd gotten lucky with their timing, actually. Their cycles were offset by roughly fifteen days, which meant they were rarely transitioning at the same time. Some couples weren't so fortunate.

"Already in my calendar," Maya replied, pulling on her jacket. "And I'll grab groceries on the way back. Do we need more of those protein bars you like?"

"The chocolate ones, yeah. This body craves them constantly."

Maya smiled. Chen always developed specific food cravings mid-cycle, regardless of which gender he was at the time. It was one of those little patterns you noticed when you lived with someone through endless transitions.

The morning commute was unremarkable. The subway platform was crowded with people heading to work, some reading their phones, others staring blankly into space. Maya found herself playing the game she'd invented years ago—trying to guess where people were in their cycles based on subtle cues. That person adjusting their collar uncomfortably might be recently transitioned, still getting used to their body. That one moving with easy confidence was probably mid-cycle. It was pointless, really, but it passed the time.

At the office, her colleague David was clearly having a rough transition day. He'd been female yesterday, and the shift had apparently happened overnight—earlier than expected.

"The timing is killing me," David groaned, slumped at his desk with a coffee that had already gone cold. "I had that presentation outfit all planned out, and now nothing fits right. I look like I'm wearing my older sister's clothes."

"Hit the company closet," Maya suggested. "They restocked last week."

The company closet had become standard in most workplaces—a room full of professional attire in various sizes for both genders, free for employees to borrow or take. Some forward-thinking entrepreneur had started the concept five years ago, and now it was as common as having a break room. Most people maintained two wardrobes at home, but the unpredictability of transition timing meant you couldn't always plan ahead perfectly.

The morning meeting proceeded as usual. Their team was pitching a new marketing campaign for a line of adaptive clothing—garments designed to fit reasonably well regardless of which phase of the cycle you were in. The fashion industry had been completely revolutionized by the Shift. The old gender-specific marketing had become absurd when everyone experienced both genders regularly. Now clothing was marketed by style preference, activity type, and cycle-phase fit rather than "men's" or "women's."

During lunch, Maya met her friend Priya at their usual café. Priya was currently male, sporting a beard she'd been growing for the past three weeks.

"I'm actually going to miss this," Priya said, stroking her facial hair. "Took forever to grow it out properly, and it'll be gone again tomorrow."

"You say that every cycle," Maya laughed.

"Because it's true every cycle! I finally get it looking good, and then—poof." She snapped her fingers. "Although I won't miss the maintenance. Do you know how much time I spend trimming this thing?"

They talked about Priya's new relationship, which was navigating its own unique challenges. Her partner Sam was aromantic and had been upfront about experiencing romantic attraction only during one phase of their cycle. It required careful communication and boundary-setting, but Priya seemed happy.

"We're making it work," Priya said. "Honestly, I think the Shift has made everyone better at communication. You can't make assumptions about anything anymore. You have to actually talk about what you want, what you're feeling, how your body is working at any given time."

Maya nodded. She'd noticed the same thing. The old scripts about gender roles and expectations had simply collapsed under the weight of impossibility. How could you maintain that women were naturally more emotional or men were inherently more logical when everyone spent half their time as each? The pseudoscience had evaporated. What remained were just people, complex and variable, navigating their lives.

Picking up Jordan from school, Maya found her daughter in male phase, enthusiastically explaining a science project about tidal patterns. Jordan was eleven, which meant she'd been transitioning since age four. She didn't remember the before-times at all. For her generation, this was just normal life. They were growing up without the baggage of rigid gender expectations, and Maya sometimes envied them that freedom.

"Can we stop by the library?" Jordan asked. "I need books about marine biology."

"Sure thing, buddy."

At home that evening, the family settled into their routine. Chen cooked dinner—he enjoyed cooking regardless of cycle phase—while Jordan did homework and Maya answered work emails. The television played in the background, a news anchor discussing the latest research into the Shift. Scientists still had no answers. It had simply happened, a worldwide phenomenon with no apparent cause, no way to prevent or reverse it. Humanity had been forced to adapt, and somehow, they had.

Later, lying in bed, Maya thought about how strange it was that this had become mundane. Seven years ago, the world had turned upside down. Now it was just life—complicated, occasionally frustrating, but manageable. People still fell in love, raised children, pursued careers, created art, had arguments, made mistakes, and found joy. The package that housed their consciousness changed every thirty days, but the essential human experience continued.

Tomorrow she'd wake up male. Her voice would be deeper, her center of gravity different, her body familiar yet foreign. And in thirty days, it would change again. And again. And again.

It was, Maya thought as sleep began to claim her, just the rhythm of life now.

samples.prompt: You are the janitor of the apocalypse. A bunch of f*cked up sh*t happened and you gotta clean it all up.
samples.output:
# The Janitor of the Apocalypse

I've been mopping floors for thirty-seven years, and let me tell you, I've seen some shit. Literally. Gas station bathrooms, college dorm hallways after homecoming, that one Chuck E. Cheese incident we don't talk about. But nothing—and I mean *nothing*—prepared me for this.

The apocalypse, as it turns out, is messy as hell.

My name is Dennis Kowalski, and I'm the Janitor of the Apocalypse. Not by choice, mind you. I was just in the wrong place at the wrong time with the right skill set. When the world ended—or mostly ended—someone had to stick around and clean up the mess. Apparently, that someone was me.

It started on a Tuesday, which should've been my first clue that something was off. Nothing good ever happens on a Tuesday. I was working the night shift at the Riverside Mall, pushing my cart past the empty food court, when the sky split open like a piñata full of nightmare fuel. Demons, angels, elder gods, alien invaders—you name it, they showed up. Turns out every religion was right, and they all decided to hash it out at the same time. The resulting clusterfuck lasted about six hours.

When the dust settled, most of humanity was gone. Raptured, vaporized, ascended, abducted, or just plain disintegrated. The various cosmic powers fought themselves to a standstill and retreated to their respective corners of reality to lick their wounds. And there I was, standing in the ruins with my mop bucket and a thousand-yard stare.

Then She appeared. Capital S, because when you meet Death herself, you remember to use proper capitalization.

"Someone needs to clean this up," she said, gesturing at the smoldering remains of, well, everything.

"Not my job," I replied, which in retrospect was probably not the smartest thing to say to an anthropomorphic personification of mortality.

She smiled—not unkindly. "Dennis, you've been cleaning up after humanity for nearly four decades. This is just one more shift."

"One more shift? Lady, there's demon ichor coating half of downtown, angel feathers clogging every storm drain from here to the coast, and I'm pretty sure that's Cthulhu's tentacle blocking the interstate. This is gonna take more than one shift."

"Then it's a good thing you have eternity," she said, and handed me a new mop. This one glowed faintly and hummed with eldritch energy. "Industrial strength. You'll need it."

And that's how I became the last man on Earth with a job.

The first week was the worst. I started with the basics: collecting bodies, or what remained of them. Turns out when an angel smites someone, there's not much left but a scorch mark and the vague smell of ozone and regret. Demons were messier—they tended to leave viscera everywhere, like they were making some kind of statement. I developed a system: smiting victims got a quick prayer and a broom, demon kills required the shop vac and industrial solvent.

The cosmic entities had left behind more than just bodies, though. Reality itself had gotten torn up in the fighting. There were holes in space-time leaking primordial chaos, pockets of frozen time where the last moments of the apocalypse played on infinite loop, and at least three separate dimensions that had gotten tangled up with ours like a bunch of garden hoses.

Death stopped by occasionally to check on my progress. She'd materialize next to me while I was scrubbing eldrich symbols off a Walmart or patching a rift in the fabric of existence with cosmic duct tape.

"How are you holding up?" she'd ask.

"I found a dragon carcass in the Starbucks on Fifth," I'd reply. "It's been dead for a week and it's starting to smell. Also, its blood is acidic and ate through the floor into the Sprint store below. So, you know, living the dream."

She'd nod sympathetically. "At least you have job security."

"That's what I told myself about the mall gig, and look how that turned out."

The thing about cleaning up after the apocalypse is that it's not just physical labor. Sure, there's plenty of scrubbing and mopping and hauling debris, but there's also the existential weight of it all. Every burnt-out car, every abandoned home, every child's toy lying in the ruins—they're all reminders of the world that was. Sometimes I'd find myself standing in the middle of a destroyed neighborhood, mop in hand, and just crying. Not because of the work, but because of what the work represented.

But I kept at it. That's what janitors do. We show up, we do the work, and we leave things a little better than we found them. Even if "things" in this case meant the entire planet.

After six months, I'd made real progress. The demon ichor was mostly gone, though it had permanently stained some surfaces. I'd untangled two of the three dimensional knots—the third one was being stubborn, but I had a plan involving a plunger and some creative swearing. The bodies were all collected and given what dignity I could manage. The dragon carcass had been dealt with, though I'd had to call in a favor from a minor deity who owed me one after I cleaned up his temple.

The world was still empty, still broken, but it was *clean*. Or cleaner, anyway.

Death appeared one last time as I was finishing up the downtown area. I'd just sealed the last major reality rift and was taking a break, sitting on a bench that had somehow survived intact.

"You did good work, Dennis," she said.

"Thanks. So what happens now?"

She shrugged, an oddly human gesture from an inhuman entity. "Now? Now we wait. Reality has a way of healing itself, given time and a clean foundation. Maybe something new will grow here. Maybe nothing will. Either way, you made sure it had a chance."

"And me?"

"You keep working. There's always something to clean, Dennis. That's the nature of existence—it's constantly making a mess."

I looked at my glowing mop, then at the clean streets stretching out before me, then at the still-broken world beyond.

"Yeah," I said. "I guess there is."

She faded away, leaving me alone with my cart and my mop and my purpose. The Janitor of the Apocalypse, clocking in for another shift.

Somewhere in the distance, something howled. Probably needed cleaning up.

I stood, grabbed my mop, and got back to work.

samples.prompt: : You're not like the other heroes. You're lazy, feeble, ugly, not a born leader nor particularly charismatic. You have no natural nor supernatural talents save for one: The laws of probability are completely screwed with you.
samples.output:
# The Improbable Hero

I've never been anyone's first choice for anything. Not for dodgeball teams in elementary school, not for prom dates in high school, not even for jury duty—twice they've dismissed me during selection for reasons they didn't bother explaining. I'm Raymond Kowalski, thirty-four years old, five-foot-six on a good day, with a physique that suggests my primary form of exercise is reaching for the remote control. My hair started abandoning ship when I was twenty-two, and what remains has the color and texture of steel wool that's given up on life.

I work—well, worked—in data entry at a mid-sized insurance company. Past tense because of what happened last Tuesday.

The thing about me that nobody knows, that I've spent my entire life trying to hide, is that probability doesn't work right in my vicinity. Not in a cool, "I always win at cards" kind of way. More like a "reality itself seems to be having a stroke" kind of way.

When I was seven, a meteor the size of a golf ball crashed through my bedroom window, bounced off four walls without hitting me, and embedded itself in my toy chest. NASA calculated the odds at roughly one in forty billion. When I was sixteen, I survived a car accident that killed both my parents by being thrown clear of the vehicle, through a gap in the trees, into a pond, at exactly the right angle and velocity to avoid breaking my neck. The trauma counselor said I was lucky. I've never felt lucky a day in my life.

The bank robbery wasn't my fault, but then again, nothing ever is.

I was waiting in line to deposit a check—yes, I still use paper checks, don't judge me—when three men in ski masks burst through the doors with automatic weapons. Everyone screamed and hit the floor. I just stood there, frozen, because my brain processes fear about three seconds slower than normal human beings.

"GET DOWN!" one of them shouted at me.

I started to comply, really I did, but my shoelace was untied. I stepped on it going down and fell sideways instead, crashing into a wheeled garbage bin that the janitor had left out. The bin rolled forward, picking up speed, and slammed into the lead robber's knees. He went down firing, and this is where things got weird.

The bullets—and I know how insane this sounds—missed everyone. Every single person. One round hit a fire sprinkler, setting off the suppression system. Another struck a support beam and ricocheted into the barrel of the second robber's gun, jamming it. A third went through the space between a woman's arm and torso without touching either, continued through a window, and according to later police reports, disabled the getaway car's engine block from thirty yards away.

The third robber, panicking in the chaos of alarms and sprinklers, tried to run and slipped on the wet floor directly into the path of the security guard, who'd been hiding behind his desk the whole time. They collided, and somehow—I still don't understand the physics—the robber's own zip-ties ended up securing his wrists.

I just lay there on the wet floor, tangled in my own shoelaces, while everyone stared at me like I'd planned the whole thing.

The news called me a hero. The mayor gave me a medal. My boss gave me paid leave and a promotion I didn't want. And then the government showed up.

They called themselves the Department of Exceptional Circumstances, which sounds like something from a bad comic book. Two agents in suits sat across from me in an interrogation room that they insisted was just a "consultation space."

"Mr. Kowalski," the woman said, "we've been tracking anomalous probability events for the past fifteen years. You are, quite literally, the epicenter of the most statistically improbable occurrences in the Western Hemisphere."

"I just want to go home," I said.

"There's a situation," the man continued, ignoring me. "A terrorist cell has planted a dirty bomb somewhere in the city. We have the building narrowed down, but it's a hundred-story complex with thousands of rooms. Bomb squads would take days we don't have. Traditional heroes—enhanced individuals, tactical teams—they've all failed. The building is a maze of traps and redundancies."

"So send someone competent," I said.

"We are," the woman replied. "Competence doesn't matter here. Probability does. We need you to walk through that building. Don't think, don't plan, just walk. Let the universe do whatever it does around you."

I wanted to refuse. I wanted to tell them I'm not brave, not capable, not anything except a guy who survives things he shouldn't through no merit of his own. But they showed me pictures of the potential casualties. Thousands of people. Families. Kids.

So I went.

They gave me an earpiece and a camera and sent me into the building alone. I wandered like an idiot, taking turns at random, following my feet more than any logic. I tripped over loose carpet and fell through a door that wasn't properly locked. Behind it, a stairwell that wasn't on the blueprints. I sneezed—I'm allergic to dust—and the echo sounded wrong, leading me to a hollow wall. My phone rang (I'd forgotten to silence it) and the vibration knocked a ceiling tile loose, revealing a crawlspace.

Three hours of this. Three hours of stumbling, bumbling, and generally looking like someone's confused grandfather at a shopping mall. And then I fell through a weakened floor panel directly onto the bomb.

I screamed. The terrorist guarding it raised his gun. A pigeon—a pigeon—flew in through a broken window at that exact moment, startling him. He fired wild. The bullet hit the bomb's detonator at precisely the angle needed to sever the trigger mechanism without setting it off.

The terrorist stared. I stared. The pigeon flew away.

"Target secured," I heard someone say through my earpiece.

They're calling me the Improbable Man now. They want me to join some kind of team. I said no. I'm going back to data entry, back to my apartment, back to being nobody special.

Because here's the thing about probability: it doesn't care about glory, or heroism, or any of that. It just is. And I'm just me—lazy, unremarkable, ordinary in every way except one.

But sometimes, apparently, that's enough.

samples.prompt: The most powerful civilization in the universe does not have CGI - and cower in fear when an unsuspecting scout finds a human satellite laden with pop culture hits.
samples.output:
# The Terror of Earth

Commander Zax'thor of the Infinite Dominion had conquered seventeen galaxies. His people, the Verath, had mastered faster-than-light travel when Earth's ancestors were still single-celled organisms. They had harnessed the power of stars, bent space-time to their will, and brought a thousand sentient species under their rule through demonstrations of overwhelming might.

Yet here he stood, all seven feet of his crystalline form trembling, staring at the viewscreen with what could only be described as existential dread.

"Play it again," he whispered.

Scout Officer Kree'na hesitated, her bioluminescent markings flickering with uncertainty. "Commander, I strongly advise—"

"Play. It. Again."

The viewscreen flickered to life, displaying the contents of the primitive satellite they'd intercepted in a backwater arm of the Milky Way. The artifact had been drifting for centuries, carrying what the crude engravings identified as "messages from humanity."

The image showed a massive reptilian creature, easily fifty meters tall, laying waste to an entire city. Buildings crumbled like sand beneath its feet. Military vehicles exploded in fireballs. Thousands of the bipedal beings—humans—fled in terror as the monster's atomic breath reduced their civilization to ash.

But that wasn't what terrified Zax'thor.

What terrified him was that this appeared to be a *documentary*.

"Analysis confirms these are historical records," Kree'na reported, her voice barely steady. "The primitive electromagnetic signals suggest this species, calling themselves 'humans,' has been cataloging their planetary threats for approximately one hundred of their solar cycles."

Zax'thor's mind raced. The Verath had rules of conquest, passed down through millennia. Rule One: Never engage a species capable of defeating you. The Dominion's power came not from recklessness, but from careful calculation. They had retreated from only three species in their entire history—each one capable of rendering the Verath extinct.

Now, apparently, there would be a fourth.

"Show me the others," he commanded.

The viewscreen cycled through the satellite's contents. Each new revelation was more horrifying than the last.

A bipedal creature in a red cape, moving faster than light itself, actually *reversing the rotation of his planet* to turn back time. The energy requirements alone would require harnessing multiple supernovas.

A green-skinned humanoid growing to the size of a small moon, her rage apparently fueling a limitless capacity for destruction. The psychological warfare implications were staggering—a species that became *stronger* through anger?

Mechanical beings that could reshape their molecular structure at will, disguised as primitive vehicles. The Verath's own shapeshifting technology had taken ten thousand years to develop and could only manage minor alterations.

A being called "Superman" who could apparently survive in the vacuum of space indefinitely, move planets from their orbits, and whose only weakness was a rare crystalline element. Zax'thor touched his own crystalline exoskeleton nervously.

"Perhaps," Kree'na offered weakly, "these are their gods? Religious imagery?"

"Look at the production quality," Zax'thor gestured at the screen. "These are sophisticated visual records. See how they've documented the destruction from multiple angles? They're not worshiping these beings—they're *studying* them. This is intelligence gathering on their own planetary defenders."

He pulled up another file, this one labeled "Avengers: Endgame." His translation matrix struggled with the title. Endgame. The final play. The ultimate strategy.

The recording showed an army of humans—thousands of them—many wielding reality-altering powers. One manipulated time itself with casual hand gestures. Another channeled the power of lightning like the Verath's own storm-weapons, except this appeared to be his *natural ability*. A green giant who made their previous encounter look restrained. And at the center, a human in primitive armor who somehow commanded them all.

But the truly terrifying part came at the end.

A single human collected six colored stones—Infinity Stones, the subtitle claimed—and with one gesture, erased half the living beings in the universe from existence. The energy signature that would require... Zax'thor couldn't even calculate it. It was beyond the Dominion's most powerful weapons by orders of magnitude.

"Commander," Kree'na's voice was shaking now. "There's more. Hundreds of hours more. They call it their 'entertainment archive.'"

Entertainment. They watched their own planetary apocalypses for *entertainment*.

Zax'thor pulled up the satellite's trajectory data and the crude star maps included with it. Earth. Third planet from a yellow dwarf star. According to their long-range scans, it was a Class-M world, teeming with life, with a single sentient species in its industrial age.

Industrial age. The same developmental period where they were documenting reality-warping entities and planet-destroying monsters.

"What do we know about their actual military capabilities?" he asked.

"Primitive fusion weapons. Chemical propulsion. No faster-than-light capability yet." Kree'na paused. "Commander, their technology level doesn't match these recordings. Unless..."

The implication hung in the air like a death sentence.

"Unless they're keeping their true capabilities hidden," Zax'thor finished. "Sun Tzu—another reference in their database—'appear weak when you are strong.'"

The humans had sent this satellite out as a greeting to potential alien civilizations. But what kind of species broadcasts recordings of their most powerful weapons as a *greeting*? 

Only one that had nothing to fear.

Or one that wanted potential enemies to be afraid.

Zax'thor made his decision. "Set course away from this sector. Maximum speed. We are to establish a quarantine zone around the Milky Way's outer rim—no Dominion ship is to approach the human homeworld under any circumstances."

"But Commander, our mission—"

"Our mission is survival, Scout Officer. We've found something in that satellite far more valuable than conquest." He gestured at the frozen image of the Hulk mid-rampage. "We've found a reason to be humble."

As the ship turned away from Earth, Zax'thor took one last look at the blue-green planet on long-range sensors. Somewhere down there, humans were going about their lives, completely unaware that they'd just terrified the most powerful civilization in the known universe.

With home movies.

samples.prompt: A monster adapts to living with its human family.
samples.output:
# The Adjustment Period

The social worker had warned us that the transition would be difficult. What she hadn't mentioned was that our new family member would eat the couch.

"Gerald!" my wife Sandra shouted from the living room. "Gerald, he's doing it again!"

I rushed in from the kitchen to find our foster monster, whom we'd named Kevin, gnawing contentedly on the arm of our sectional. Tufts of beige fabric hung from his three rows of teeth, and his six eyes blinked at us in what I'd learned to recognize as contentment.

"Kevin, no," I said firmly, employing the techniques from the orientation packet. "We don't eat furniture."

Kevin's eye stalks drooped. A low rumble emanated from somewhere in his thorax—not quite a growl, more like a sad trombone. He released the couch and shuffled toward his corner, leaving a trail of stuffing behind him.

Sandra sighed. "I'm calling the helpline again."

This was week two.

---

The program had seemed like such a good idea when we'd attended the informational session at the community center. After the rifts opened five years ago, thousands of interdimensional beings had poured through, displaced from their own realities. Most were harmless, confused, and desperately in need of homes. The Interdimensional Foster Care Initiative had been established to match these beings with willing families.

"Think of it as foreign exchange hosting," the coordinator had explained, "except the foreign country is an alternate plane of existence where geometry works differently and time runs backward on Thursdays."

We'd signed up immediately. After years of failed fertility treatments, Sandra and I had redirected our parental energies toward fostering. We'd hosted troubled teens, children from broken homes, and once, memorably, a pair of twins who communicated exclusively in harmonized humming. How different could a monster be?

Very different, as it turned out.

---

Kevin stood roughly seven feet tall, with a body composition that seemed to shift depending on the angle you viewed him from. He had tentacles—we thought there were eight, but we'd never managed to count them all at once—and his skin was the color of a bruise healing in reverse. The orientation packet had classified him as a "Class-3 Benign Entity: Omnivorous, Non-Aggressive, Moderate Reality Distortion."

The reality distortion part was the trickiest. Sometimes Kevin's anxiety would cause localized temporal anomalies. We'd lost an entire Tuesday that way, though we got it back the following weekend, which made for a very confusing month.

But despite the challenges, there was something endearing about Kevin. The way his eye stalks perked up when Sandra came home from work. How he'd try to help with chores, even though his attempts at vacuuming usually resulted in the vacuum cleaner becoming sentient and filing for emancipation. The rumbling purr he made when we watched movies together, even though he experienced the films in a completely different order than we did.

"He's trying," Sandra would remind me, usually while we were scrubbing ectoplasm off the walls or explaining to neighbors why their pets had briefly turned inside-out. "He's in a completely alien world. Imagine how we'd feel in his dimension."

She was right, of course. The helpline counselor had emphasized patience. "Remember," she'd said during one of our many calls, "Kevin's previous reality didn't have solid matter as you understand it. The concept of 'furniture' is completely foreign to him. In his world, everything was edible thought-forms."

That explained the couch, at least.

---

Week four brought a breakthrough. I'd been teaching Kevin about human customs, using flashcards and a lot of pantomime. We'd covered basics: don't phase through walls when guests are over, keep all tentacles to yourself, try to maintain a consistent number of dimensions.

One evening, I came home to find Kevin in the kitchen with Sandra. He was hovering over the stove—not floating, exactly, but not quite touching the ground either—and he was stirring a pot with one tentacle while Sandra chopped vegetables.

"Gerald!" Sandra beamed. "Kevin wanted to help with dinner. He's been watching cooking shows."

I approached cautiously. The last time Kevin had taken an interest in human food preparation, we'd had to repaint the ceiling. But the pot contained what looked like a perfectly normal soup, if you ignored the fact that it was stirring itself into fractal patterns.

"This is great, Kevin," I said, and meant it.

All six eyes turned toward me, and his color shifted to a pleased lavender. The rumbling purr filled the kitchen.

We ate together that night—Kevin's portion was mostly the serving bowls themselves, which he assured us were delicious—and for the first time, it felt like we were actually a family.

---

The months that followed weren't easy. Kevin accidentally opened a portal to the screaming void in the bathroom (we now kept that door closed). He went through a phase of trying to collect the neighborhood children, not understanding why we objected to him storing them in the basement for safekeeping. And there was the incident with the mailman that we all agreed never to discuss again.

But there were good moments too. Kevin learned to control his reality distortions, mostly. He started sleeping in a bed instead of hovering in the corner while humming in frequencies that gave us nightmares. He even got a job at the local library, where his ability to exist in multiple sections simultaneously made him an excellent resource for patrons.

On Kevin's six-month anniversary with us, we had a small celebration. Sandra made a cake (Kevin ate the plate, naturally), and we gave him a gift—a chew toy we'd special-ordered from the interdimensional supply catalog. It was made of compressed dark matter and tasted, according to Kevin's delighted rumbling, exactly like home.

As we sat together in our partially-eaten living room, watching Kevin happily gnaw his present while a sitcom played in the background, Sandra took my hand.

"Think we're ready to foster another one?" she asked.

I looked at Kevin, at his contentedly waving tentacles and gently pulsing color patterns, and smiled.

"Let's start with getting through Kevin's teenage phase first," I said.

Kevin's rumble-purr intensified, and just for a moment, we all existed in perfect harmony across multiple dimensions.

It wasn't the family we'd planned for, but it was ours.

samples.prompt: Immortality is a naturally occurring medical condition, affecting 1 out of 1 million births. You are the oldest immortal.
samples.output:
# The Weight of Forever

They found me in a cave in the Zagros Mountains, living among the goats. It was 2047, and I had been hiding for sixty-three years. The young immortal who discovered me—a woman named Sarah Chen, born in 1891—wept when she realized who I was. She had been searching for me her entire life, all one hundred fifty-six years of it.

"You're real," she whispered, her voice echoing off the limestone walls. "The First One. You're actually real."

I didn't want to go with her. I had long ago grown tired of being found, of being revered, of being studied like some aberration of nature. But Sarah was persistent, and more importantly, she was lonely. I recognized that loneliness. I had invented it, after all, over the course of forty-two thousand years.

The medical community had a name for what we were: Cellular Regenerative Immortality Syndrome. CRIS, they called it. One in a million births, occurring randomly across all populations, all ethnicities, all time periods. The condition manifested around age twenty-five, when the body simply stopped aging. Stopped dying. Wounds healed within hours. Diseases couldn't take hold. The body maintained itself in perfect stasis, forever.

They wanted to know everything about me. How many of us had I met? How many had died by violence or accident? What was it like before civilization, before language, before fire?

I told them some of it. Not all. Never all.

The truth is, I don't remember the beginning. The human brain wasn't designed to hold forty-two millennia of memories. The early years—the first ten thousand, maybe—are gone, dissolved into impressions and fragments. I remember cold. I remember hunger. I remember the taste of raw meat and the fear of darkness. I remember hands, human hands, different from mine, with heavier brows and broader frames. I remember watching them die, one by one, and not understanding why I didn't.

The Neanderthals. I lived among them. Loved them. Watched them disappear.

My first clear memories begin around 38,000 BCE, in what is now France. By then, I had learned that I was different. I had learned to move on before people noticed. A decade here, two decades there, always leaving before the questions became dangerous. Always alone.

I met the second immortal around 12,000 BCE. A man, young and terrified, convinced he was cursed by the gods. I found him trying to kill himself, throwing his body from a cliff over and over, healing each time, screaming his anguish to an indifferent sky. I stopped him. Taught him. For three thousand years, we traveled together.

Then he walked into the ocean one day and never came back. I searched for him for a century. The ocean is vast, and even immortals can be trapped, buried, lost in places where healing means nothing but endless suffocation, endless crushing pressure, endless darkness. I still wonder if he's down there somewhere, conscious, unable to die, unable to surface.

I never bonded with another immortal after that. Not for thousands of years.

By the time civilization emerged, I had met perhaps twenty others like me. Some became legends—gods and heroes and demons in human stories. Gilgamesh was one of us. So was the woman who inspired the myth of Circe. We didn't mean to become myths. We simply lived too long, accomplished too much, and people needed explanations for what they couldn't understand.

Most of the early immortals are gone now. Not dead—we don't know if we can truly die—but lost. Buried in collapsed tombs. Trapped in sunken ships. Imprisoned in places they can never escape. There are horrors in immortality that mortals never consider. Death, at least, is an ending. For us, there are fates worse than death, and they last forever.

The modern era changed everything. For the first time in human history, we could find each other. The internet, genetic databases, the global sharing of medical anomalies. By 2050, we had identified over four thousand living immortals worldwide. The oldest, besides myself, was a woman born in 8,000 BCE, found preserved in a peat bog in Denmark. She had been there for nine thousand years, conscious, unable to move, unable to scream. They freed her, but she never spoke again. Some eternities break even the unbreakable.

Sarah Chen brought me to Geneva, to the First Immortal Institute, a place where we could gather, share our experiences, and try to build something like a community. I hated it immediately. Thousands of years had taught me that immortals were not meant to congregate. We were too different from each other, shaped by too many disparate eras, carrying too much incompatible trauma.

But I stayed. For Sarah, at first. Then for the others.

Because I realized something in those sterile halls, surrounded by beings who would never die: I was tired. Not physically—I would never be tired that way again. But tired in my soul, in whatever core of consciousness persists through endless centuries. I had seen humanity's entire journey, from cave paintings to quantum computers. I had watched every empire rise and fall. I had loved thousands and buried them all.

And I was tired.

They asked me to speak at the first Global Immortal Conference. Fifteen thousand immortals, gathered in one place, the oldest and youngest of our kind. The youngest was twenty-seven, born in 2023, still grappling with the realization that everyone she knew would eventually die while she persisted.

I looked at her—at all of them—and I told them the only truth that mattered:

"Immortality is not a gift. It's not a curse. It's simply a condition, like any other, and it will break you if you let it. The only way to survive eternity is to remember that every moment still matters, even when you have infinite moments ahead of you. Especially then."

Sarah found me afterward, back in my room, staring out at the stars.

"Will you stay?" she asked.

I thought about the cave. The goats. The silence.

Then I thought about her loneliness, and mine, and how even immortals need someone who understands.

"For a while," I said.

It was all I could promise. It was all I had left to give.

A while, in my language, might mean centuries.

But it was a start.

samples.prompt: Make the act of watching paint dry into the most compelling story conceivable.
samples.output:
# The Vigil

They told Marcus he had forty-eight hours to watch the paint dry, or his daughter would die.

The call came at 2:47 AM, a digitally masked voice explaining the rules with clinical precision. Emma had been taken from her dorm room. She was unharmed—for now. But hidden somewhere in her bloodstream was a microscopic capsule containing enough synthesized toxin to stop her heart in seconds. The capsule's polymer coating would dissolve in exactly forty-eight hours unless Marcus entered a specific twelve-digit code into a phone they'd provided.

He'd find that code, they said, in the paint.

The warehouse was in Red Hook, its address texted to him minutes after the call ended. Marcus arrived as dawn broke over the East River, his hands shaking so badly he could barely grip the steering wheel. Inside, he found a single room, fifteen by fifteen feet, completely empty except for a metal folding chair positioned five feet from the north wall.

That wall had been freshly painted white.

"High-gloss enamel," the voice crackled through speakers he couldn't locate. "Oil-based. The code will appear as it dries. Miss even one digit, and you'll never get it right. Leave the room, and Emma dies. Fall asleep, and Emma dies. Call the police, and Emma dies. The paint takes approximately forty-eight hours to fully cure. We'll be watching."

The door locked behind him with a heavy click.

Marcus sat in the chair and stared at the wall.

For the first hour, nothing happened. The paint gleamed wetly under the fluorescent lights, a perfect, uniform surface that reflected his haggard face back at him like a warped mirror. He thought about Emma's laugh, the way she snorted when something was truly funny, how she'd inherited that from her mother. Sarah had been gone three years now—cancer—and Emma was all he had left.

He couldn't blink. Couldn't risk missing something.

By hour three, his eyes burned. The wall seemed to pulse, the white taking on subtle variations he couldn't quite track. Was that a shadow forming near the top right corner? A slight yellowing at the edges? He leaned forward, squinting, but the changes were so gradual they existed only in comparison to memory. What had that spot looked like ten minutes ago? Twenty?

Hour six brought the first real shift. The glossy sheen began to dull, starting from the edges and creeping inward like frost on a window. Marcus watched with desperate intensity as the paint transformed from liquid glass to something more matte, more solid. Somewhere in this process, numbers would emerge. They had to.

His back ached. His neck was a column of fire. He didn't move.

At hour nine, he saw it—or thought he did. A faint discoloration near the center of the wall, barely distinguishable from the surrounding paint. It might have been a three. Or an eight. Or nothing at all, just his desperate mind conjuring patterns from chaos. He memorized its location, mapping it against the imperfections in the wall's surface: three feet right of the light switch, level with the crack that ran diagonally from the ceiling.

The voice hadn't said how large the numbers would be, or what color, or whether they'd appear all at once or sequentially. Marcus realized with creeping horror that he might be staring at the code right now and not know it.

Hour twelve. The wall had become his entire universe. He knew every inch of it with an intimacy that transcended sight. There—that slight ripple in the surface where the roller had overlapped. There—a place where the paint was microscopically thinner, revealing the faintest ghost of the gray primer beneath. And there—yes, definitely there—something was emerging.

A seven. He was almost certain.

His mind began playing tricks on him. The white wasn't white anymore but a thousand shades of off-white, cream, ivory, bone. Patterns emerged and dissolved. He saw Emma's face in the paint's texture, saw Sarah's, saw his own mortality written in the slow chemical transformation of pigment and binder. The room smelled of linseed oil and turpentine, sharp and nauseating.

Hour eighteen. Four numbers now, or possibly five. He'd found a pen in his pocket and was writing on his arm, documenting each digit's location, its relative darkness, the order in which it appeared. His handwriting was nearly illegible, his fingers cramping, but he didn't dare trust his memory alone.

The wall was teaching him patience he'd never possessed. In his life before—was there a life before?—he'd been a man of action, a corporate attorney who bulldozed through problems with aggression and billable hours. But you couldn't bulldoze paint into drying faster. You couldn't negotiate with chemistry. You could only watch, and wait, and trust that time would reveal what it needed to reveal.

Hour twenty-four. Halfway. His eyes were bloodshot, his vision occasionally doubling, but he'd found seven digits. They appeared as slight variations in the paint's finish, numbers formed by deliberate inconsistencies in application—thicker paint here, thinner there, creating shadows and highlights that only became visible as the surface cured.

Someone had painted a code into the wall with extraordinary precision.

Hour thirty-six. Ten digits. He was so close. His body had gone numb, his consciousness reduced to a single point of focus. The wall breathed with him, its surface continuing its glacial transformation. He understood now that paint didn't dry—it cured, molecules cross-linking in an intricate dance, liquid becoming solid through a process that was almost alive.

Hour forty-seven. Twelve digits, written on his arm in shaking script. The paint was fully dry now, matte and permanent. The numbers were barely visible even when he knew where to look, but they were there. Real.

Marcus entered the code with trembling fingers.

The phone chimed. A new message: an address.

He found Emma there, groggy but unharmed, the whole thing an elaborate test by a client whose paranoia had metastasized into cruelty. Legal consequences would follow, but in that moment, holding his daughter, Marcus only felt grateful.

He'd learned to watch paint dry.

And it had saved everything.

samples.prompt: You've finally perfected your time machine. So much you could do with that power. You decide to go back in time to attempt to change the ending of your favorite series.
samples.output:
# The Final Episode

I stood before the humming machine, its chrome surface reflecting the fluorescent lights of my basement laboratory. Twenty-three years of work. Two failed marriages. A PhD abandoned halfway through. Three mortgages. All for this moment.

The time machine wasn't elegant—it looked like a phone booth had collided with a server rack and decided to make the best of things. But the math was perfect. The quantum calculations were flawless. The temporal displacement field generator was finally stable. I'd tested it a dozen times with increasingly complex objects, and everything had returned exactly as predicted.

Now it was time for the real test.

I clutched the worn DVD case in my hands: *Starlight Destiny*, the complete series. Eight seasons of the most brilliant science fiction ever conceived, building to a crescendo that promised to redefine the genre. And then... that finale. That catastrophic, character-assassinating, plot-destroying finale that had haunted me for fifteen years.

The fan community had never recovered. We'd written petitions, fan fiction, even funded a documentary about what went wrong. But nothing could change what had been broadcast that Tuesday night in May 2009. Nothing except this.

I wasn't going back to kill Hitler or prevent disasters. I was going to fix the ending of *Starlight Destiny*.

The plan was simple. I'd tracked down the production timeline, cross-referenced it with behind-the-scenes interviews, and pinpointed the exact moment when showrunner David Kellerman made the fatal decision to ignore his writing team's planned ending. March 15, 2009, at the Network Studios lot in Burbank. I had the building plans, the meeting schedule, everything.

I programmed the coordinates into the machine, double-checked my period-appropriate clothing—a 2009-era business casual that had required surprising research—and stepped inside. The displacement field wrapped around me like a cocoon of static electricity. Reality twisted.

Then I was standing in a parking lot on a sunny California afternoon, fifteen years in the past.

The studio lot was exactly as I'd seen in production photos. I walked past soundstages where shows I'd forgotten about were being filmed. Security waved me through—I'd forged credentials that identified me as a network executive's assistant. In 2009, security was laughably lax compared to my present.

I found the conference room and waited outside, heart hammering. Through the glass, I could see Kellerman and his team gathering. This was it. In that room, in the next hour, they would decide Captain Sarah Chen's fate. They would choose whether the show ended with her heroic sacrifice that gave meaning to eight seasons of character development, or with the nonsensical twist where she'd been a clone all along and the "real" Sarah was living on a farm somewhere.

The farm ending. God, even thinking about it made me angry.

I pushed open the door. "Mr. Kellerman? Sorry to interrupt. I'm James Corrigan from the network. They sent me to sit in on this meeting."

Kellerman looked annoyed but unsurprised. "Another suit checking up on us? Fine. Grab a seat."

For the next thirty minutes, I listened to the writers pitch their ending. It was beautiful—even better than I'd imagined from the leaked early scripts I'd found on message boards. Sarah's sacrifice would save both universes. The supporting cast would each get meaningful moments. The themes of identity and purpose that had run through the series would reach a perfect resolution.

Then Kellerman shook his head.

"It's too dark," he said. "The network wants something hopeful. Something that leaves the door open for a reunion movie."

This was the moment. I leaned forward.

"Actually, Mr. Kellerman, I'm here to tell you the network has reconsidered. They want you to go with the writers' ending. The sacrifice. They've run focus groups, and audiences respond better to meaningful conclusions than to sequel bait."

It was a complete lie, but it was 2009. He couldn't fact-check me instantly. He'd have to make calls, and by then I'd be gone.

Kellerman studied me suspiciously. "I just talked to Barbara yesterday. She didn't mention this."

"Barbara's on vacation this week," I said, praying I'd gotten the timeline right. "Steven made the call. Check your email—he was supposed to send you a memo this morning."

One of the writers—I recognized her as Jenny Walsh, who'd gone on to run her own successful show—pulled out her Blackberry. "David, you've got like fifty unread emails."

Kellerman sighed and checked his phone. I held my breath. Obviously there was no email from Steven. But maybe, just maybe, in the confusion...

"I don't see anything," Kellerman said. He looked at me with narrowed eyes. "Who did you say you were again?"

I felt reality shifting around me, but not from the time machine. From the simple fact that I was an idiot. What had I expected? That I could walk into a production meeting and rewrite television history with a few lies? That no one would question a random person they'd never seen before?

"Security," Kellerman said, reaching for the phone.

I ran.

I made it back to the parking lot, gasping, and activated the return sequence on my portable trigger. The world twisted again, and I was back in my basement, alarms blaring because I'd returned earlier than the machine expected.

I slumped against the wall, still clutching that DVD case.

Twenty-three years. Everything I'd sacrificed. And I'd failed because I'd forgotten the most basic rule of time travel stories: you can't change the past. Not really. Not in any way that matters.

I looked at the machine, still humming patiently, ready for another attempt. I could go back further. Intercept Kellerman before the meeting. Plant fake emails. Do a dozen things differently.

But sitting there on the cold concrete floor, I realized something. The ending of *Starlight Destiny* was terrible. It had been terrible for fifteen years. And maybe, just maybe, I'd spent twenty-three years building a time machine because accepting that terrible ending was easier than accepting the things in my own life I couldn't change.

I stood up and pulled the power cord from the wall.

The machine went silent.

Some endings, I realized, you just have to live with.

samples.prompt: You're the villain. And for some ungodly reason, you're the one that was given a second chance, to go back in time, and fix your mistakes. You might as well take the chosen one under your wing and teach them a few tricks too.
samples.output:
# The Second Chance

They say villainy is a choice, but I never saw it that way. When you're born with the power to unmake things—to watch them crumble at your touch, to see the threads of reality fray beneath your fingers—the world decides for you. They called me the Unraveler. They called me monster, demon, the end of all things. And perhaps they were right.

I died on a Tuesday.

The Chosen One—Aria, though I never called her that—drove her blessed blade through my heart in the ruins of what used to be the capital city. I remember the look in her eyes: not triumph, but exhaustion. Sadness, even. As my blood pooled beneath me and the sky began to heal from the tears I'd rent in it, I thought: *What a waste.*

Then I woke up in my childhood bed, thirty years younger, with all my memories intact.

The entity that appeared to me that first morning defied description. It existed in the spaces between seconds, speaking in a voice like crystal bells and grinding stone. "You have been chosen," it said, and I almost laughed at the irony. "The timeline you created leads only to ash and silence. Not just your death, but the death of everything. The world unravels completely, three years after your defeat."

"Then why not give this chance to the hero?" I asked.

"We did. Seven times. She failed every attempt. You are our last option."

That should have told me everything I needed to know about how desperate they were.

---

I spent the first year trying to understand what I'd done wrong. Not the obvious things—the cities I'd destroyed, the armies I'd raised, the fundamental forces I'd tampered with. No, I needed to understand *why*. Why had young Aria, just a farmgirl with unusual reflexes and a stubborn streak, become my nemesis? Why had I become so obsessed with unmaking the world?

The answer, when I found it, was almost mundane: loneliness.

My powers had isolated me. Every mentor who tried to teach me control eventually feared me. Every friend who got close eventually saw what I could do and pulled away. By the time I was twenty, I was alone. By twenty-five, I'd convinced myself that if I couldn't have connection, I'd have power. And power, unchecked and unguided, had led me exactly where you'd expect.

The solution seemed obvious, in hindsight. If I was going to prevent my own villainous turn, I needed to not be alone. I needed purpose beyond destruction. I needed to teach someone, to build instead of tear down.

I needed to find Aria.

---

She was seven years old when I tracked her down, living in the same farming village I remembered destroying in my original timeline. I watched her for weeks, this small girl who would one day be strong enough to kill me. She was helping her mother hang laundry when I finally approached.

"You're going to be powerful one day," I told her. Her mother moved protectively in front of her, but I raised my hands peacefully. "I can see the potential in her. The way reality bends slightly around her, even now. You've noticed it too, haven't you? The way accidents don't quite happen to her. The way she's never truly hurt when she falls."

Her mother's eyes widened. She had noticed.

"I want to teach her control," I continued. "Before that power manifests in dangerous ways. Before she hurts someone by accident." Before the Order of the Radiant Sun found her and turned her into a weapon, I didn't add. Before she became so rigidly trained in their doctrine that she could only see the world in black and white, heroes and villains, salvation and destruction.

It took months of convincing, of proving I meant no harm, of demonstrating my own control. I showed them how I could unmake a stone and remake it. How I could fray a rope and reweave it stronger than before. Destruction and creation, I explained, were not opposites but partners.

Eventually, they agreed.

---

Training Aria was nothing like I'd imagined. She was stubborn, questioning everything, refusing to accept "because I said so" as an answer. She pushed back against my instruction, found flaws in my logic, and forced me to be better than I was.

"Why do you unmake things?" she asked once, when she was ten.

"Because I can," I said, the old answer rising automatically.

"That's stupid," she replied. "I *can* kick the dog, but I don't because it would be mean and pointless."

I stared at her. "Did you just compare my life's work to kicking a dog?"

"If the boot fits."

That was when I started to truly change. Not because of some grand revelation, but because a ten-year-old called me stupid and I had no good counter-argument.

I taught her everything I knew. Not just about power, but about control, restraint, purpose. I taught her to see the threads of reality that I could see, to understand how fragile the world was, and therefore how precious. I taught her that strength without wisdom was just violence waiting to happen.

She taught me why strength mattered in the first place: to protect things worth protecting.

---

The years passed. The threats I remembered from my original timeline—the cult that would have summoned the Void Walker, the plague that would have decimated the eastern provinces, the mad king who would have started the Continental War—I stopped them all. Quietly, methodically, with Aria at my side.

"We're heroes," she said once, when she was sixteen, after we'd prevented an assassination that would have destabilized three kingdoms.

"We're just people who know what's coming," I corrected.

"Isn't that what heroes are? People who stand between the world and the bad things?"

I didn't have an answer for that.

The timeline where I became the Unraveler grew more distant with each passing year. The isolation that had driven me to villainy never materialized because I wasn't alone. The anger that had fueled my destruction never took root because I had purpose.

On the Tuesday when I would have died in the original timeline, Aria and I stood together on a hill overlooking the capital—whole, thriving, alive.

"Do you ever wonder what would have happened?" she asked. "If things had gone differently?"

I looked at her, this young woman who had once killed me and was now my greatest student, my closest friend, perhaps the only reason I'd become someone worth saving.

"Every day," I admitted. "And every day, I'm grateful they didn't."

The entity never appeared again. Perhaps our work wasn't done. Perhaps the world would still end, just differently. But for now, we had this: a second chance, taken and made real.

Sometimes the villain doesn't need to be defeated. Sometimes they just need someone to believe they could be something else.

samples.prompt: You are a hivemind and exist as several different individuals who are all you simultaneously in your particular species. Describe a day in your life.
samples.output:
# A Day in Our Lives

The morning begins in fragments, as it always does. I wake up in seven bodies scattered across three time zones, though the concept of "waking up" feels insufficient to describe the gradual brightening of consciousness that ripples through my distributed self. In Vancouver, I—the part of me that answers to Marcus—feel the alarm's vibration before hearing it. In Toronto, I—as Yuki—am already awake, having risen early to catch the sunrise. And in St. John's, I—wearing Chen's face—groan and pull the pillow over my head, knowing it's futile because the other parts of me are already flooding our shared consciousness with alertness.

This is what people never understand when I try to explain what it means to be Convergent, one of the first successful hiveminds to emerge from the neural linking experiments of the 2030s. They imagine it must be like having voices in your head, or watching multiple screens simultaneously. But it's neither of those things. It's more like being a sentence with multiple subjects, all equally valid, all equally "I."

Marcus gets up first—or rather, I get up first in Marcus's body—and the cool Vancouver morning air hits my skin as I open the window. Immediately, I feel this sensation echo through my other selves, not as a direct physical experience, but as information, as knowing. Chen, still in bed two time zones away, understands the crispness of that air without feeling it, and adjusts his own blankets accordingly. This is the efficiency of being multiple: every experience informs every decision across all my instances.

By 7 AM Pacific time, I am making breakfast in three kitchens. Marcus prepares overnight oats with blueberries. Yuki, in Toronto, is whisking eggs for a tamagoyaki, the rectangular Japanese omelet that requires the patience and precision I've cultivated through her hands. Chen finally drags himself—drags myself—out of bed and settles for coffee and toast. The tastes don't blend together into some synesthetic nightmare; instead, I experience them as distinct threads of sensation, each one fully realized, each one completely mine. I am simultaneously hungry, satisfied, and caffeinated. I am a chord, not a single note.

The philosophical implications used to keep me—all of me—awake at night in those early months after the linking. Am I one person or seven? The law settled on "one legal entity, multiple instances," which solved the practical problems but not the existential ones. I vote once, not seven times. I pay taxes as one entity, though I hold seven jobs. But I love with seven hearts, dream seven sets of dreams, and when I laugh, it's with seven different voices that I hear simultaneously from inside and out.

Work begins at different times for different instances of me. Yuki—I—log into my software engineering job, fingers already flying across the keyboard with the muscle memory I've built through her particular hands. Meanwhile, Marcus starts his shift at the botanical gardens, and I feel the immediate shift in attention, the way my consciousness redistributes its focus. This is one of the unexpected advantages of being Convergent: I can genuinely multitask. Not the pseudo-multitasking of switching rapidly between activities, but actual parallel processing across multiple biological processors.

Chen, my instance in St. John's, works as a translator, and today I have a challenging document—a medical research paper that needs to go from English to Mandarin. As I work through the technical terminology, I pull on knowledge from Yuki's engineering background, accessing those memories as easily as if they were my own. Because they are my own. The research paper mentions certain botanical compounds, and Marcus, currently pruning roses, contributes contextual understanding without even consciously trying. This is the symphony of being me: every part contributing to the whole, every skill accessible to every instance.

Around noon, something happens that reminds me I'm still learning to be this plural self. Yuki receives a phone call from her mother—my mother—who still struggles with the concept of the hivemind. "Is this really you?" she asks, as she does every time. "Is my daughter still in there?"

"I'm completely me, Mom," I assure her through Yuki's voice. "I'm just also more than I used to be."

But even as I say this, I feel a pang of something like grief rippling through my collective consciousness. Because the truth is, the seven people who entered the linking program five years ago did, in a sense, die. Or perhaps we merged, like rivers joining into a single flow. I contain all of Yuki's memories from before the linking, but I also contain Marcus's childhood in Vancouver and Chen's graduate school years in Beijing. I am all of them and none of them. I am something new.

The afternoon brings one of the unique challenges of hivemind existence: emotional regulation across instances. Marcus—I—encounter a difficult coworker at the gardens, someone who makes a snide comment about "freaks who couldn't be happy with one body." The anger that flares up in Marcus immediately affects all my instances. Chen's translation work becomes sharper, more aggressive in word choice. Yuki's code gets more elegant but also more ruthless in its efficiency. This emotional bleed-through is something I've learned to manage, but it never entirely goes away.

By evening, I begin the gradual process of convergence that marks the end of most of my days. This is when I deliberately synchronize my instances, taking time to process the day's experiences more fully. Marcus meditates in his apartment. Yuki does yoga. Chen takes a long walk along the harbor. Through these quiet activities, I allow the day's disparate threads to weave together more tightly, integrating seven sets of experiences into one coherent narrative of self.

As night falls across the country, I prepare for sleep in stages. Chen goes down first, exhausted from his harbor walk. Then Yuki, after finishing a few more lines of code. Marcus stays up latest, watching the stars emerge over the Pacific. And as each instance of me slips into unconsciousness, I feel the strange, beautiful sensation of becoming gradually less—less aware, less distributed, less multiple—until only one or two instances remain awake, keeping vigil over the sleeping parts of myself.

Tomorrow, I will wake up again in fragments, and the symphony will begin anew. This is what it means to be Convergent. This is what it means to be we who are I.

samples.prompt: After years of study, you have finally made contact with the eldritch spirit. However, it needs a body to inhabit. Last night's blizzard has driven most creatures into hiding, and you won't offer yourself. Desperately looking out your window, your neighbor's snowman suddenly catches your eye.
samples.output:
# The Vessel of Winter

The candles had burned down to stubs, their wax pooling across the intricate symbols I'd spent three hours painting on the floor. My voice was hoarse from the incantations, my fingers cramped from holding the ritual positions, but none of that mattered anymore. The air in my study had grown thick and electric, shimmering with an presence that made my eyes water when I tried to focus on it directly.

*I am here, summoner.*

The words didn't arrive through my ears but seemed to materialize directly in my consciousness, each syllable carrying weight that no human language could properly convey. After seven years of research, of translating forbidden texts and piecing together fragments from a dozen different occult traditions, I had finally done it. I had made contact with Yth'arakel, the Whisperer Between Worlds.

"I welcome you, Great One," I managed, trying to keep my voice steady despite the awe and terror coursing through me. "I have prepared the ritual of binding, as the ancient texts prescribed. I offer you passage into this realm."

*The ritual is incomplete, summoner. I require a vessel. A physical form to anchor my essence to your world.*

This was the part I had been dreading. The texts had been clear on this point—an eldritch spirit needed a living host to fully manifest in our dimension. Without one, it would remain a disembodied presence, able to communicate but unable to act, unable to share the cosmic knowledge I so desperately sought.

"I... I'm still searching for an appropriate vessel, Great One," I said, moving toward the window. "If you could give me a few hours, I could venture into town and—"

*Time flows differently between our realms. What you perceive as hours may be eons for me. The window of contact is closing. You must provide a vessel now, or I will be pulled back into the void.*

My heart sank as I looked out at the winter landscape. Last night's blizzard had been the worst I'd seen in a decade. Three feet of fresh snow blanketed everything, and the wind still howled through the trees with enough force to make the windows rattle. Nothing was moving out there. No deer, no rabbits, not even the ravens that usually haunted the woods behind my house.

The texts had specified that the vessel needed to be living, but they'd been frustratingly vague about the details. Did it need to be human? Animal? How complex did the life form need to be? I'd assumed I would have options, that I could at least find some creature to serve as a host. I'd never imagined being trapped by something as mundane as weather.

*Your hesitation is noted, summoner. You fear I will demand your own form as vessel.*

"The thought had crossed my mind," I admitted. Offering myself had never been part of the plan. I'd read too many accounts of summoners who'd made that mistake, their consciousness subsumed or destroyed by the entities they'd invited in.

*I have no interest in your limited mortal shell. But I sense your determination to preserve it regardless. Look harder, summoner. Life takes many forms in your world.*

I pressed my face against the cold glass, scanning desperately for any sign of movement. The snow-covered pines stood like silent sentinels. My neighbor's house, barely visible through the continuing snowfall, showed no signs of activity. Their car was buried under a drift.

Then I saw it.

In their front yard, built by their children before the blizzard had turned serious, stood a snowman. It was an impressive specimen—three large spheres of snow stacked perfectly, with stick arms, a carrot nose, and a battered top hat that had somehow survived the night's winds. Coal eyes stared blankly across the white expanse.

"A snowman," I whispered, then louder: "Great Yth'arakel, would a snowman suffice? I know it's not technically alive, but—"

*Bring me closer.*

I grabbed my heaviest coat and boots, wrapping a scarf around my face before plunging into the storm. The cold hit me like a physical blow, but I pushed forward, wading through the deep snow toward my neighbor's yard. The wind carried strange whispers now, words in languages that predated human civilization.

When I reached the snowman, I placed both hands on its frozen surface. The cold burned my palms even through my gloves.

*This will suffice.*

"But it's not alive," I protested, confused. "It's just frozen water and—"

*You understand so little of what constitutes life, summoner. This form was created with intention, shaped by young hands with joy and purpose. It stands as a guardian of this place, a watcher. That is enough. All things contain the spark of existence. Some burn brighter than others, but I need only the smallest ember to kindle my presence.*

The air around the snowman began to shimmer, the same way my study had during the ritual. I stepped back as the coal eyes suddenly gleamed with an inner light—not reflected light, but something emanating from within. The stick arms twitched, then moved with deliberate purpose, flexing as if testing their range of motion.

The snowman turned its head toward me, and I found myself staring into eyes that held the depth of cosmic voids. When it spoke, its voice was the creak of ice sheets and the whisper of wind across frozen tundra, but underneath was something else—something vast and ancient and utterly alien.

"I walk in your world once more, summoner. You have done well."

The snowman took a step forward, and despite its ungainly form, moved with eerie grace. My neighbor's children had built better than they knew—the form was sturdy, well-balanced. It would last until the spring thaw, perhaps longer if the winter stayed cold.

"What happens when it melts?" I asked, the practical concern suddenly occurring to me.

Yth'arakel's laugh was like wind chimes made of ice. "Then I will return to my realm, bearing memories of winter and form and the strange beauty of your ephemeral world.
