She was in ancient Bulgaria, on the eve of an actual battle, in the body of an actual warrior who was expected to actually fight with an actual sword against actual Byzantine soldiers who would actually try to kill her.

"Oh, shit," she whispered in English, then caught herself. "I mean... yes. Fevered. Definitely fevered. I should rest."

**Part III: The Night Before**

Vulfila spent the next hour exploring the apartment, his warrior's mind cataloging everything. The place was clearly a dwelling, but for someone of incredible wealth—the craftsmanship of every object was beyond anything he'd seen in Constantinople itself. The cold box that kept food fresh without ice. The indoor plumbing that delivered clean water at will. The library of thousands of books, all printed with identical precision.

He found identification papers for "Violet Chen, Age 24." So this was whose body he inhabited. A woman, then, despite the masculine clothing and warrior-like paint. In his time, shield-maidens were rare but respected. Perhaps it was the same here, in this impossible future.

The buzzing device—a "phone," according to the papers near it—kept receiving messages. Someone named Marcus was insistent. Finally, Vulfila pressed the glowing surface and spoke: "I cannot attend your... gathering. I am unwell."

The response came immediately: "Dude, we've been planning this for a YEAR. You can't bail on the finale! We need our Tremere!"

Tremere. He'd seen that word on the papers with the colored stones. Some kind of ritual? A battle of sorts? Despite everything, Vulfila felt a familiar pull—the call to stand with one's companions, whatever the challenge.

Meanwhile, Violet had retreated to Vulfila's tent, her mind racing. She'd spent years studying medieval history, playing tabletop RPGs, immersing herself in fantasy worlds. But this was real. The leather of the armor was real. The sword was real. The men outside preparing to kill or be killed were real.

She pulled out Vulfila's belongings, looking for clues. A small wooden cross—Christian, then. Letters from someone named Irmingard. A whetstone, well-used. And a small journal, written in Latin, which she could somehow read.

"Tomorrow we fight for Khan Tervel," the last entry read. "I do not know if I will survive, but I know I will fight with honor. If I fall, may God receive my soul, and may Irmingard remember me as I was."

Violet's hands shook. This man—this real person whose life she'd somehow stolen—might die tomorrow. And she had no idea how to stop it or how to get back to her own time.

Outside both their dwellings, in their respective times, the night deepened, and two displaced Goths faced impossible dawns.

samples.prompt: One of the most powerful, high profile superheroes is sick of being second-guessed and criticised by TV talking heads and similar commentators for their actions. Their solutions for this issue is ... creative.
samples.output:
# The Luminary Solution

The morning talk show host leaned forward with that practiced expression of concern that Marcus had come to loathe. "But don't you think, Luminary, that perhaps you should have waited for the police to establish a perimeter before confronting the Crimson Reaper? Three city blocks were damaged in that fight."

Marcus Chen, known to the world as Luminary—the man who could harness pure solar energy, who had saved the eastern seaboard from the Cascade Event, who had personally prevented no fewer than seventeen apocalyptic scenarios—smiled tightly. "The Reaper was about to detonate a quantum bomb that would have vaporized half the city. I had forty-five seconds."

"Yes, but the property damage—"

"Is significantly less than half a city being vaporized."

The host's co-anchor chimed in, her voice dripping with false sympathy. "I think what we're asking, Luminary, is whether someone with your... immense power... should perhaps exercise more restraint? Show more consideration for the average citizen?"

Marcus had stopped doing interviews after that. But it didn't matter. The commentary continued without him.

Every news cycle brought fresh criticism. When he stopped the Tectonic Twins from triggering an artificial earthquake, the geological experts questioned his methodology. When he intercepted a meteor headed for downtown Chicago, the astrophysicists suggested three "better" approaches he could have taken—all of which would have required equipment he didn't have and time he didn't possess. When he saved a school bus full of children from plunging off a collapsed bridge, someone calculated that the G-forces the children experienced during his rescue might have caused minor whiplash, and shouldn't he be liable?

The final straw came during a prime-time roundtable discussion where five people who had never faced danger more serious than a delayed flight spent forty-five minutes dissecting his decision-making during the Void Incursion. They sat in their comfortable chairs, sipping water, explaining what he should have done differently while extradimensional horrors were tearing through reality itself.

That's when Marcus had his idea.

The next morning, he made an announcement through his publicist: Luminary was launching a new initiative called "The Commentary Corps." Any media personality, pundit, or expert who had publicly criticized his methods would be invited to join him in the field. They would be given front-row seats to superheroic crisis response. They could offer their expertise in real-time.

The response was immediate and predictable. Most declined. But several—those who had been particularly vocal, who had built entire segments around critiquing superhero "overreach"—couldn't refuse without looking like hypocrites. Their audiences wouldn't let them.

Todd Brentwood, host of "The Real Truth Hour," was the first to accept. He'd spent three months running segments on Luminary's "excessive force" and "cowboy mentality." Marcus picked him up personally, arriving at the studio in his full costume, solar energy crackling around his form.

"Ready to see how it's done?" Marcus asked with a smile that didn't reach his eyes.

The first call came twenty minutes later. Graviton, a mid-level supervillain with the power to manipulate local gravity fields, was tearing through a downtown shopping district. Marcus flew toward the scene with Todd held carefully in an energy field beside him.

"So," Marcus said conversationally as they streaked through the sky at Mach 2, "what's your assessment?"

Todd's face had gone pale, his carefully styled hair whipping in the wind. "I... what?"

"Your expert analysis. You've spent hours explaining what I do wrong. Here's your chance to guide me through it." Marcus descended rapidly, the sounds of screaming and crashing growing louder. Below them, cars floated twenty feet in the air while Graviton laughed maniacally. "Should I approach from above or below? Consider that he can reverse gravity in a fifty-foot radius. You have four seconds."

"I don't—I'm not—"

"Three seconds. People are in those cars, Todd."

"Above! No, wait—"

Marcus dove from above, inverted his energy field at the last second to counteract Graviton's powers, and delivered a precisely calibrated strike that knocked the villain unconscious without causing permanent injury. The cars settled gently to the ground. Total elapsed time: twelve seconds.

"Good news," Marcus said, floating back to where Todd hovered in his energy bubble, the commentator's face now slightly green. "You're right that I could have approached from below. Of course, that would have given him a clear shot at the suspended vehicles, and if he'd dropped them out of panic, we'd have had seventeen casualties. But you were fifty percent correct! That's not bad for your first time."

They responded to four more incidents that day. Each time, Marcus politely asked for Todd's real-time strategic input. Each time, Todd stammered or froze or gave advice that would have led to disaster. By the evening, when Marcus dropped him back at the studio, Todd looked like he'd aged five years.

His show that night was notably subdued. "Perhaps," he told his audience, "crisis response is more complex than it appears from a distance."

Marcus invited six more critics to join him over the following weeks. A former military general who'd called him "tactically incompetent." A superhuman ethics professor who'd written papers on his "moral failures." A popular podcaster who'd made her name on hot takes about superhero accountability.

He was unfailingly polite. He never put them in actual danger. But he made them watch, made them feel the weight of split-second decisions, made them understand the difference between theoretical criticism and practical reality. He asked for their input with genuine courtesy, then showed them—in real-time—why their suggestions wouldn't work.

Most stopped commenting on his methods afterward. A few became actual advocates, explaining to their audiences the impossible complexity of superheroic crisis response.

The ethics professor, Dr. Sarah Chen, became a regular consultant, but now she rode along once a month to stay grounded in reality. "I was teaching theory," she admitted publicly, "without understanding the practice. That was arrogant."

Marcus never gloated. He simply continued his work, saving lives, stopping threats. But the nature of commentary changed. People were more cautious, more humble. They'd seen what happened when theory met reality.

And on his worst days, when the weight of responsibility threatened to crush him, Marcus would remember Todd's face during that first incident—the moment of understanding, of recognition that heroism wasn't a thought experiment conducted in safety, but a series of impossible choices made in the space between heartbeats.

It wasn't perfect. Some critics remained, as they should. Accountability mattered. But now the conversation had changed. Now it included respect for the reality of the work.

Sometimes, Marcus reflected, the best way to handle criticism wasn't to ignore it or fight it, but to invite it into the light—and let reality do the teaching.
